<workItem aoparent="1" aoplan="1" aorelease="2" aostream="1" hasoriginalestimates="false" id="11" orderrangeidentifier="plan-1" sortorder="9" status="0" type="1" version="2">
<title><![CDATA[Download a Log File ]]></title>
<details><![CDATA[As a user i should be able to click on the log column so that a log file in text format will get downloaded to the user's local system, opened automatically .

Process Flow
The registered user logins to the system
He/She launches the ETL console which when a new screen is opened in the new tab
By clicking on the project\ Profile will expand the list of processes present in the project
By clicking on the process hyperlink , will redirect the user to the logging page where are the logs created are listed in the tabular format
Click on the corresponding process log column so that a log file get downloaded ,
Acceptance Criteria
Whenever a log file gets downloaded successfully , success message is displayed in the Message screen.
In case of errors, internet connection errors the corresponding values are displayed in the message screen.
The user should be able to download the logs in XML, Text formats
]]></details>
</workItem>
<workItem aoparent="1" aoplan="1" aorelease="2" aostream="1" hasoriginalestimates="false" id="12" orderrangeidentifier="plan-1" sortorder="10" status="0" type="1" version="2">
<title><![CDATA[Access Log Detail Page]]></title>
<details><![CDATA[As a registered user i should be able to click on the process name, log column at the record level so that a log file will be opened in a separate window.

Process Flow
The registered user logins to the system
He/She launches the ETL console which when a new screen is opened in the new tab
By clicking on the project\ Profile will expand the list of processes present in the project
By clicking on the process hyperlink , will redirect the user to the logging page where are the logs created are listed in the tabular format
Click on the corresponding process name hyperlink so that a new windows is opened with detailed explanation of the messages
Acceptance Criteria
Should open the process in a separate window
The Message Displayer will have a whole section of logs basing on the Filter of Step and Level
The user should have an option for the message format to be displayed in XML, Text Format
]]></details>
</workItem>
<workItem aoparent="1" aoplan="1" aorelease="2" aostream="1" hasoriginalestimates="false" id="13" orderrangeidentifier="plan-1" sortorder="11" status="0" type="1" version="2">
<title><![CDATA[Applying Filter on Logging page]]></title>
<details><![CDATA[As a logged in user i want to sort basing on the start date , End date and from the list of the available value in the drop down so that system will fetch the record basing on the conditions selected.

Process Flow
The registered user logins to the system
He/She launches the ETL console which when a new screen is opened in the new tab
By clicking on the project\ Profile will expand the list of processes present in the project
By clicking on the process hyperlink , will redirect the user to the logging page where are the logs created are listed in the tabular format
Select the drop down value and press go button so that appropriate record are fetched
Acceptance Criteria
The activemark status in the Record grid area shows that a process is completed successfully.
The Cross mark shows that a log file is created with Errors in the process
]]></details>
</workItem>
<workItem aoparent="1" aoplan="1" aorelease="2" aostream="1" hasoriginalestimates="false" id="14" orderrangeidentifier="plan-1" sortorder="12" status="0" type="1" version="2">
<title><![CDATA[Accessing Logging Summary page]]></title>
<details><![CDATA[As a logged in user i want to access the logging summary page from the main menu so that the control is redirected to the logging page .

Process Flow
The registered user logins to the system
He/She launches the ETL console which when a new screen is opened in the new tab
By clicking on the project\ Profile will expand the list of processes present in the project
By clicking on the process hyperlink , will redirect the user to the logging page where are the logs created are listed in the tabular format
Acceptance Criteria
The user who is accessing , should be a registered user with active subscription.
There has to be one project and one process created to access the logging page and if no project, state are created the page will be shown as “No Logs present.”
The trial users will not able to access the logging page ,
]]></details>
</workItem>
<workItem aoparent="1" aoplan="1" aorelease="2" aostream="1" hasoriginalestimates="false" id="15" orderrangeidentifier="plan-1" sortorder="13" status="0" type="1" version="2">
<title><![CDATA[Manage job event using scheduler]]></title>
<details><![CDATA[As a user i should be able to create a job event from the profile section of the scheduler so that a job gets run at definite , indefinite intervals of time and duration.

Process Flow
user logins to the DBSync instance and navigates to project->Process and click on the scheduler tab so that a new popup opens up.
user gives in the Name of the job which is nothing but the process name (Should auto populate basing on the process selected)
User should be able to set the type and frequency so that job runs at the specified intervals of time
All the saved jobs should get populated in the grid at the bottom of page
user should be able to Edit, Delete, view the job event from the action button of the grid.
on clicking Edit, View the form fields will be displayed in the form above the grid
on clicking on the delete will prompt an alert saying “Are you sure you want to Delete” with ok and cancel button , on clicking ok will erase the entry from the db, on clicking cancel will redirect the user to the previous screen.
Acceptance Criteria
A single process will have only one job running.
The process can have other job event created if there are no active jobs running in the background.
In case the frequency is selected the minimum interval allowed is N min .
A scheduled job is editable only when the process is in running state (Isrunning= true)
]]></details>
</workItem>
<workItem aoparent="1" aoplan="1" aorelease="2" aostream="1" hasoriginalestimates="false" id="16" orderrangeidentifier="plan-1" sortorder="14" status="0" type="1" version="2">
<title><![CDATA[Adding Template\ Importing PDL to workspace]]></title>
<details><![CDATA[As a logged in user i want to Add the Template from the specific template section so that the whole template gets added to the project\profile.

Process Flow
The registered user logins to the system
He/She launches the ETL console which when a new screen is opened in the new tab
By clicking on the Library Tab, a pop is opened as shown in the wireframe
User can scroll down from and select from available templates
User should also have an option to search basing on template title which will return all the available standard templates suiting the search string
From the template section user can click on “ADD” button for the PDL to get added to the project
Clicking on More Details section will expand the view of the same page with features , faq sections
Acceptance Criteria
User should be able to add template for which he has valid adapter license to and if not the ADD button is disabled.
Collapsible form will open on clicking on the “More Details” Button which is a part of Listing page
]]></details>
</workItem>
<workItem aoparent="1" aoplan="1" aorelease="2" aostream="1" hasoriginalestimates="false" id="17" orderrangeidentifier="plan-1" sortorder="15" status="0" type="1" version="2">
<title><![CDATA[Accessing PD Listing page]]></title>
<details><![CDATA[As a logged in user i want to access the PDL summary page from the main menu (Library )so that the control is redirected to the standard PDL listing page .

Process Flow
The registered user logins to the system
He/She launches the ETL console which when a new screen is opened in the new tab
By clicking on the Library Tab, a pop is opened as shown in the wireframe
User can scroll down from and select from available templates
User should also have an option to search basing on template title which will return all the available standard templates suiting the search string (Search should return basing on title , description i.e global search)
User will also have an option to sort with default view, Ascending order , descending order
Acceptance Criteria
The user will only be able to Import the template after selection of the template
All the standard templates are arranged in alphabetical order
]]></details>
</workItem>
<workItem aoparent="1" aoplan="1" aorelease="2" aostream="1" hasoriginalestimates="false" id="18" orderrangeidentifier="plan-1" sortorder="16" status="0" type="1" version="3">
<title><![CDATA[Advanced Query Designer]]></title>
<details><![CDATA[As a logged in user i want to edit the predefined query, design an query from the controls available so that after execution will return a resultset.

Process Flow
The registered user logins to the system
He/She launches the ETL console which when a new screen is opened in the new tab
Clicking on the project will launch the list of all the project which the user has access to
Clicking on a particular Process from the left side navigation will load all the states of a process
Basing on the adapter selected, user selects the “Define Rule” button so as to define condition or alter the pre defined query from the query designer page
The query designer will be opened in the new tab i.e default simplified view
The user has to click on the “Toggle View” to change the simplified view to Advanced view.
By clicking on the schema objects will expand them with available fields, and checking them will be populated in the query pane
user will be able to set conditions from the available operators and also apply Group By and Order By conditions by selecting on the appropriate Tabs
User can run the query from the Run button in the result pane section
Acceptance Criteria
User will be exposed with the query , as he can only set the condition
The advanced view will show the predefined queries of the map, reader , status writer for Pre-defined templates
Whenever there is no query present , user can generate a query from the options available
The initial landing page of the query view is the simplified query view where a user can switch the mode to advanced mode from here.
]]></details>
</workItem>
<workItem aoparent="1" aoplan="1" aorelease="2" aostream="1" hasoriginalestimates="false" id="19" orderrangeidentifier="plan-1" sortorder="17" status="0" type="1" version="2">
<title><![CDATA[Simplified Query Designer]]></title>
<details><![CDATA[As a logged in user i want to create condition for a query and apply logic between the conditions so that it result will be shown at the run time.

Process Flow
The registered user logins to the system
He/She launches the ETL console which when a new screen is opened in the new tab
Clicking on the project will launch the list of all the project which the user has access to
Clicking on a particular Process from the left side navigation will load all the states of a process
Basing on the adapter selected, user selects the “Define Rule” button so as to define condition or alter the pre defined query from the query designer page
The query designer will be opened in the new tab i.e default simplified view
User can Add a row a for defining the new condition and if he has to delete the unwanted condition can be done by clicking on Delete row hyperlink
user will be able to set conditions from the available operators and apply the logic between various conditions from the text box and save the logic for future use
User can run the query from the Run button in the result pane section
Acceptance Criteria
User will not be exposed with the query , as he can only set the condition and logic between the conditions within this page
The initial landing page of the query view is the simplified query view where a user can switch the mode to advanced mode from here.
]]></details>
</workItem>
<workItem aoparent="1" aoplan="1" aorelease="2" aostream="1" aoteam="2" hasoriginalestimates="false" id="20" orderrangeidentifier="plan-1" sortorder="18" status="0" type="1" version="3">
<title><![CDATA[Accessing Query Designer Page]]></title>
<details><![CDATA[
As a logged in user i want to access the query designer page from the state listing screen (of Button Define Rule) so that query designer will be opened in a new tab in a simplified view.
Process Flow
The registered user logins to the system
He/She launches the ETL console which when a new screen is opened in the new tab
Clicking on the project will launch the list of all the project which the user has access to
Clicking on a particular Process from the left side navigation will load all the states of a process
Basing on the adapter selected, user selects the “Define Rule” button so as to define condition or alter the pre defined query from the query designer page
The query designer will be opened in the new tab

Acceptance Criteria
The query designer view will be simplified while opening from the state listing page
Basing on the adapter selected the query designer will have the list of the standard , custom object in the drop down of the screen
User should be able to toggle between simplified, advanced views of the screen,
on selecting the “Switch Mode” will only change the view of the page (not opened in new tab or pop up)
]]></details>
</workItem>

Hello Anil Bhimineni,

thanks for providing the error details. In order to upload the XML you can click on More > Attach files, I create the plan from the XML you posted, but it did not work, so please try to attach the exported XML file.

The error you are getting seems to be the same as described in this bug, we thought we had already fixed this. Just to be sure - you experience this problem with Portfolio 1.10.0, is that correct?

Could you try the workaround described in the linked bug ticket? And please upload the XML file so that we can investigate your problem.

Thank you for your help,
best regards,
Albert

Hello Anil Bhimineni,

are there any updates on this issue? Did the workaround help? Did you see the image about how to attach files?

Thanks for your answers,
best regards,
Albert

Hi Albert ,

I have deleted that plan and created a fresh one and as of now there seem to be no problem, My earlier version was older and i have updated to new one .
This is the same issue as JPO-350.

Hello Albert,

What would be the end date for releasing the fix of the reported issue?

item.title: [JRA-42108] javascript error - Uncaught Unable to find either an issueId or projectId to submit the attachment to
item.description:
Currently, AUI forms with a file input seem to need an 'id' attribute to stop a runtime javascript failure that breaks all other scripts.

Lack of an 'id' element, or adding with/without a value but not being a valid issueID/projectID results in a javascript console error:

Uncaught Unable to find either an issueId or projectId to submit the attachment to.

Odd behaviour then occurs if there is already an 'id' form attribute on submit that, a new file picker element dynamically injected, with some related text, which is not desirable.

  1. This requirement is asserted on all forms but should only apply to JIRA forms with a specific class selector for the cases that need it (there isn't one)
  2. Usage of 'id' with no prefix is an undocumented requirement for forms with file sections. 'id' is too generic, and is likely to be already used, and should be something else, 'relatedIssueOrProjectId' for example. If this script targeted applicable forms appropriately, the use of 'id' or not would not matter
  3. The related script should detect lack of presence of a more appropriately named required attribute rather than breaking
item.summary: javascript error - Uncaught Unable to find either an issueId or projectId to submit the attachment to

comments.comment:
Andy Brook: Could you please give me more details about what exactly are you trying to achieve? As I understand you are trying to use some internal JIRA javascript component(InlineAttach.FormPresenter, InlineAttach.AjaxPresenter or InlineAttach.Form).

Thanks

Regards,
Grzegorz

Hi Grzegorz,
I'm not using any internal javascript that I'm aware of. I have a p2 addon, rendering its own page in an admin context, it contains a simple velocity rendered aui form, with a file picker.

The problem occurs during this (initialization):

Attachment is {1} but the largest allowed attachment is {2}.","upload.error.bad.response":"Cannot attach file {0}: Unexpected server response.","upload.error.unknown.status":"Cannot attach file {0}: Unknown server error ({1}).","upload.error.auth":"Cannot attach file {0}: You do not have permission to attach a file to the issue.","upload.error.badrequest":"Cannot attach file {0}. Browser made bad request to the server.","upload.error.server":"Cannot attach file {0}: {1}","upload.cancel":"Cancel","upload.file.remaining":"{0} - {1} left.","upload.file.waiting":"{0} - waiting.","upload.file.stalled":"{0} - stalled.","upload.checkbox.title":"Clear check box to prevent file being attached","upload.xsrf.timeout":"Cannot attach file {0}: Your session has timed out or you were logged out. Please save your work and reload the page.","upload.error.unknown":"Cannot attach file {0}: Unknown server error.","upload.progress.title.waiting":"Waiting for other uploads to complete.","upload.progress.title.running":"Uploading.","upload.progress.title.unknown.stalled":"{0}, stalled.","upload.progress.title.known":"{0} - {1}, {2} left.","upload.progress.title.known.stalled":"{0} - {1}, stalled.","upload.kilobyte":"{0} kB","upload.kilobyte.part":"{0}/{1} kB","upload.megabyte":"{0} MB","upload.megabyte.part":"{0}/{1} MB","upload.gigabyte":"{0} GB","upload.gigabyte.part":"{0}/{1} GB","upload.seconds":"{0} sec","upload.minutes":"{0} min","upload.hours":"{0} hr","upload.hours.minutes":"{0} hr {1} min","upload.bytes.per.second":"{0} B/sec","upload.kilobytes.per.second":"{0} kB/sec","upload.megabytes.per.second":"{0} MB/sec","upload.error.no.access":"Browser does not have permission to access {0}.","upload.error.does.not.exist":"{0} does not exist.","upload.error.client.unknown":"An unknown error occured on the browser while trying to attach {0}: {1}.","upload.error.too.many.files":"You are trying to attach {0} files. Only {1} files can be attached at a time.","upload.error.server.no.reply":"Cannot attach file {0}: Unable to communicate with JIRA.",tr:function(key){if(arguments.length==0){return undefined}else{if(arguments.length==1){return this[key]||key}else{if(this[key]){var args=InlineAttach.copyArrayLike(arguments);args[0]=this[key];return AJS.format.apply(AJS,args)}else{return key}}}},fileSize:function(){if(arguments.length==0){return undefined}else{var key,b=InlineAttach.Text._classifySize(arguments[0]);if(b.unit===kB){key="upload.kilobyte"}else{if(b.unit===MB){key="upload.megabyte"}else{key="upload.gigabyte"}}if(arguments.length==1){return this.tr(key,b.convert(arguments[0]))}else{var result=new Array(arguments.length);for(var i=0;i<arguments.length;i++){result[i]=this.tr(key,b.convert(arguments[i]))}return result}}},currentOutOfTotalSize:function(current,total){var b=this._classifySize(total),key;if(b.unit===kB){key="upload.kilobyte.part"}else{if(b.unit===MB){key="upload.megabyte.part"}else{key="upload.gigabyte.part"}}return this.tr(key,b.convert(current),b.convert(total))},_classifySize:function(size){var base;if(size<=kBMax){base=kB}else{if(size<=MBMax){base=MB}else{base=GB}}return{unit:base,convert:function(s){return InlineAttach.Text._toDisplay(s/base)}}},time:function(seconds){if(seconds<60){return this.tr("upload.seconds",Math.floor(seconds))}else{var minutes=seconds/60;if(minutes<60){return this.tr("upload.minutes",Math.floor(minutes))}else{var hours=Math.floor(minutes/60);minutes=Math.floor(minutes%60);if(minutes>0){return this.tr("upload.hours.minutes",hours,minutes)}else{return this.tr("upload.hours",hours)}}}},rate:function(bytesPerSecond){if(bytesPerSecond<=bMax){return this.tr("upload.bytes.per.second",InlineAttach.Text._toDisplay(bytesPerSecond))}else{if(bytesPerSecond<=kBMax){return this.tr("upload.kilobytes.per.second",InlineAttach.Text._toDisplay(bytesPerSecond/kB))}else{return this.tr("upload.megabytes.per.second",InlineAttach.Text._toDisplay(bytesPerSecond/MB))}}},_toDisplay:function(number){if(number<0.005){return"0"}else{return(Math.round(number*100)/100).toFixed(2)}}}})();return InlineAttach});AJS.namespace("AJS.InlineAttach",null,require("jira/attachment/inline-attach"));

I guess this is driven by the web-resource bundle:

    <web-resource key="jemh-profile-${project.version}" name="JEMH Profile Javascript and CSS Resources">
        <dependency>jira.webresources:jira-global</dependency>
        <dependency>jira.webresources:autocomplete</dependency>
        <dependency>jira.webresources:global-static</dependency>
        <dependency>com.atlassian.auiplugin:ajs</dependency>
        <resource type="download" name="jemhprofiles.js" location="/templates/com/javahollic/jira/jemh/ui-js/profile.js" />
        <context>jemh.ui.profiles</context>		
    </web-resource>

It seems like the use of one of these is triggering this expectation (am I using something I shouldn't be here!)

Thanks Andy, after checking I can say that in fact it is a bug in JIRA, which is colliding with AUI.

There is a workaround for this problem, try adding "ignore-inline-attach" class to input element.
Yep, verified that works for me, will use now thanks!

item.title: [JRA-27613] Alternative JIRA Views
item.description:
Background
JIRA does not natively support the idea of field level security (JRA-1330), the most popular of which is the ability to the hide Time Tracking fields from customers (JRA-2364). We know that a lot of customers really want a way for JIRA to solve this kind of problem.

View Ports
Internally at Atlassian we have been throwing around the idea of what we call "View Ports". The idea behind this is that admins can configure an alternative view of the JIRA View Issue screen for different groups. One of the items that can be configured is the ability to choose what fields are shown in the View Port.

Example Scenario
You have a company that specialises in custom development solutions and have 10 internal staff members with 200 external customers. You want to manage all your issues in one JIRA project but you do not want to expose the time tracking fields to your customers.

View Port Solution
1. Admin creates a JIRA group for all the 'external customers'.
2. Admin then creates a View Port for this group only.
3. Admin configures the View Port to show all fields except time tracking.

When anyone in the 'external customers' group logs into a specific url, they are taken to this View Port. They will not be able to login into the normal JIRA system.

Comments Please
We'd love to get your feedback in this solution and if it would work for your company.
item.summary: Alternative JIRA Views

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Would this solution also be able solve hiding the time tracking information (including the initial estimate and spent effort) on

  • the search result list (where the user can manually add the column)?
  • in Greenhopper, when you wish to include the time tracking information for the developers?
  • when receiving email-notifications when the change includes updated time tracking data?
  • when accessing Jira via the WebService/REST apis?

Regards, Michael

Hi,

some questions:

  • "logs into a specific url": unclear for me - what is this URL ? why a different one ?
  • can these external customers still access the parts of Confluence that are configured for them ?
  • can they still search & filter for issues ?

Background:
We are exactly in the configuration you describe (multiple external customers, internal developers, one JIRA).
Customers have access to the Wiki for documentation & status reports, including links that lead them to JIRA lists (e.g. open bugs, resolved bugs that are deployed and can be tested & closed).

If the external customers can't login to the normal JIRA system, is the View Port view only? Or do they have the ability to create/edit issues?
I think for us this is not a solution of our "hide time tracking problem", because some time tracking information has to be hidden even for internal users.

Hi,

I also have the same questions commented above, and our business case is also similar to the issue description. But in our case we might require hiding certain other fields in addition to time tracking fields.

Does View Port Solution cover all the types of screens including 'Create Issue', 'Edit Issue', 'View Issue' and transition screens?

Also I would like to know whether this is just 'hiding HTML page elements'. If so I guess people will be able to inject data into fields when editing issues.

Many thanks!

–
Shaakunthala

The View Port solution sounds good, but as already mentioned above, there are some open questions. Is the solution really secure and does hide the information complete from not allowed users (all screens, transitions, issue navigator, mails, different export types, SOAP, ...)? Do View Port only support groups or roles, too?

Why don't you just add the functionality of the Field Security Plugin to the JIRA core and expand it for JIRA system fields?
This plugin works great and should be able to solve all problems mentioned in JRA-1330 and JRA-2364 when it gets expanded for JIRA system fields.

Wolfgang,

Field Security Plugin does NOT wokr great. It has big security hole - EACH user can switch on advanced issue filtering and use those 'hidden' fields in JQL query. That means for clever users all data is available - even if not displayed on screen. Example - each user can run query "timespent>10h and timespent<20h" and will see all issues where time logged is between 10h and 20h.
We have Jira 4.3.4
Nice that this is taken seriously, however, this doesn’t seem to solve that we cannot use Greenhopper for our customers because that means showing them timetracking-information.

The Field Security Plugin works great - for custom fields. But Radoslaw is right, it is buggy regarding JIRA system fields. Thats why i would be happy when Atlassian includes the functionality to the JIRA core and extend it fully functional to all system fields.
If a user navigate to this View Port URL, will all other projects this user has access to still be available or he will have to switch to another URL for another View Port on another project?

I would want a view port to control which fields can be seen or are hidden according to all the usual controls used in Permissions and Notification schemes, e.g. "Assignee, Reporter, Role, Group, ...". Also as others have pointed out in earlier comments, there are many places where a field can be viewed, e.g. a column in the Issue Navigator, History tab of an issue, email templates, REST access - which ones are implemented would have to be carefully documented.
This sounds promising! I would also want to see the ability to add Project Role in addition to Security Group.

It looks like most of the commentators are assuming that View Ports will be a part of the full-blown JIRA core - which could lead of course to the potential problems outlined (access to field via columns in navigator, JQL etc.)

To me (based on Roy's issue description)

[...] When anyone in the 'external customers' group logs into a specific url, they are taken to this View Port. They will not be able to login into the normal JIRA system [...]

it looks like (or better: I hope) that View Ports could be a new dedicated JIRA front end (and back end ...?) build from scratch and focused entirely on fulling just some few goals

  • view an issue
  • view some or all fields, based on security settings (group or roles)
  • e.g. comment on issue
  • trigger (not really executing) a workflow request (e.g. to resolve or close an issue)

Without all the features like

  • Issue History
  • Issue Activity
  • Agile view
  • Search (or extremely limited search e.g. subset like quick search field with a subset of quick search features)
  • etc. etc. etc.

This could reduce the internal JIRA overhead to verify all the permissions (AFAIK one reason why field level security was dropped) just by excluding all functions which could be used by 'clever' users to bypass the View Port permission and to access unprotected fields.

To take another point of view:
If I take a high-level view on JIRA and reflecting since Version 2.x, it still can't deny it's roots:
A software to help developers (target group A) to create software and - BTW - to enable non-developers (target group B) within the organization to participate in this process in an easy and user-friendly way. And based on this approach, Atlassian had added more and more power features over the time by always trying to maintain an easy access to this power features.

Why not putting aside this approach and take a new point of view?

"We would like to add new target group customers (target group C, a person outside the organization running JIRA) - and what do they really need to participate in this process?"

Typical scenarios not easy (sometimes nearly impossible without accepting a redundancy and inefficient workflows) to be accomplished with JIRA (always assuming that JIRA is maintaining the development process within the organization):

  1. giving customers some kind of not tightly coupled and non-power user role (not technically speaking) within the development process
  2. running JIRA as a ticket / support system
  3. a combination (software development, support systems and multiple customers participating in development process and requesting support).

Even Atlassian is running multiple JIRA instances

  • external JIRA for customers to participate
  • dedicated JIRA as support system
  • additional internal (...?) JIRA to run the development ...?

To sum up:
Probably it makes sense that Atlassian tries a new approach to tackle the requirements by e.g. starting an additional, new front end (to get rid of the problem how to protect all the get-data-entry points of current JIRA front end), especially tailored for the role external customer/company who will take part in JIRA.

Ahmad,

Your comments are right on the money. One of the largest problems that we have with 'hiding' things is that they are shown in so many different places, and it would not be feasible to re-write large chunks of JIRA (all of it) to hide everything people want.

A "ViewPort" is an alternative front-end to JIRA. It's advantages are:

  • We can build up fields one by one. So field-level security is enabled by default.
  • We can map / rename fields. So your customers / business users can use their terminology.
  • We can create a lighter, simpler interface. For example, customers raising support tickets with you, don't generally care about dashboards, projects etc
  • We can have more fine-grained security. By using JQL as the 'security' mechanism, you can even further limit what a subset of users can see. As example would be showing customers issues updated in the last year.
  • Ability to embed. Often you would like to embed a simple JIRA interface inside another application.

Longer-term, other options:

  • Different licensing options. Users licensed to use a ViewPort could be priced differently to those accessing JIRA directly
  • Automatic field values. If you embed a ViewPort in another application, that application could provide some of the field values rather than getting them from the user directly (think support use-case where you want to pre-fill the environment from your CRM for example).
Hopefully there will be good plugin-points for this feature when released

Hi,
The Viewport does sound interesting and I can see uses for it, but I still think that we require the field security plugin. We are currently adopting the field security plugin and I'm generally happy with it and think other than a few tricky places (like the advanced search), it does a pretty good job of hiding the fields. I do want the ability for our external users to comment on issues, have a few workflow actions and even use the filters, dashboards to get a view of their own issues. It doesn't sound like Viewport will go that far?
I think that Atlassian did a really good job with the issue level security which we are also using in conjunction with the field level security plugin, so I'm disappointed that we can't go one step further and get the security down to the field level as well. After all you solved JRA-9 and the time field was permeated all over the system, I"m sure you could do the field level security. Besides the plugin gets you more than halfway there.
Please consider....thanks..

Susan,

Can you please outline your use-case? What fields are you hiding from whom? I believe that ViewPort would be perfect for your use-case (obviously for you to judge), but more info would help us.

Hi Scott,
Thanks so much for taking such an interest!! My company provides hosting for our Portfolio Analytics Software applications. We have about 40 clients on hosting and anywhere from 1 to 50 users within each client. We want to allow our external clients to access JIRA to raise support issues ranging from Hosted access problems to Software problems. Users within each client should be able to see each other's issues and add themselves as watchers for notifications. The Security Level schemes work beautifully for this purpose.
The fields that we want hidden within each issue are Time Tracking, SLA timers (VertygoSLA) and some single select custom fields (Especially field "Client" which has the list of all our active Clients). We don't want our clients to even know those fields exist if they are running a filter or a gadget.
I hope that helps and I'm happy to provide more information.
Thanks...Susan

Susan,

How many issues would each of your clients create? How advanced searching would they need? If there were just two lists - open issues, and closed issues, would that suffice?

A "ViewPort" would have more restricted searching, and missing things like 'Dashboards', 'Bulk Edit', 'Projects' etc. But it would be a better (read:simpler) interface for more casual users.

How do you achieve your use-case today?

Hi Scott,

The number of issues from client to client varies greatly. There could be hundreds of issues for some of the clients. They would need to be able to see open and closed issues, but differentiate between those raised by them versus all the issues in their organization.
Dashboards, Bulk Edit and Projects is not really required. But search ability is essential.

Currently we have a custom front-end portal built by a third party, that uses the API to raise the issues and then retrieve the issues for viewing. We allow them to comment as well on the issues. But our clients have asked for more and more features that would require extensive development in our portal.

The list of bugs/enhancements they have requested are:

  • View other attachments (not just their own)
  • Attach Screenshots, attachments on the create issue screen
  • Sorting, delete ability on comments, attachments
  • Local time zone ability
  • Filter, search by any/all of the fields
  • Export search results to excel

It soon became apparent to us that they could easily have all those features if we just opened up JIRA to them. BUT there are other fields that we want to keep hidden from them such as the time tracking, VertygoSLA fields and a number of custom fields.

Thanks once again. Cheers...Susan

Susan,

It sounds like we're on the same page then. My ideal scenario is that the end user would see different tabs, each containing issues, and this would be configurable. So you could have a tab for 'my open issues', 'my closed issues', 'my organisations open issues' etc.

Then a very simple free-text search on the client side.

From your list of enhancements, viewing attachments, attaching on the create screen etc would be things we're looking at. Things like 'export to Excel', advanced search and timezones I can't see making it into a version anytime soon.

It does seem that you have some pretty advanced interactions with your customers (them wanting Excel exports!), and this particular issue won't solve them in the short-term. But let me know if any other requirements come to mind - it is very useful to hear from you.

Hello,

It seems that this approach would solve the basic needs regarding hiding e.g. the time tracking field.
We're using Jira as communication platform with our customers in order to identify any type of request (feature, customization). For customizations we've to provide time estimations to the customer (needed for the billing).
We use the time tracking features in order to measure exactly how long the effective implementation took, sometimes it's above or under the estimation. In any case, this is only for internal use and we don't which in any way to communicate time tracking information with our customers.

When can we expect this improvement?

Cheers,

JJ

This would be great. But wondering whether we need to duplicate some efforts in creating screens per issue type and then additionally creating View Ports per group. If both could be clubbed together somehow (may be in the screen administration, also chose which group can see the field, the default is everyone)

Lot of questions about this:

  • Will there be separate schemes in the view port for notifications? We would like to send more notifications internally but we can't because it would spam the external users with notifications.
  • Will it support the ability to map groups or projects to different view port schemes? View requirements will vary by project and external user(s).
  • Can workflow states be mapped to different names in the view port? For example, I would like to group our internal development states into one simple "In Progress" state that is viewable by an external users. If view port notification schemes are supported, this could help reduce spam as the viewport user should not receive notifications for all the internal state changes. They would only receive notifications when their mapped state changed.
  • The request above for states is actually a general use-case for any enumerated value.
  • Assuming users can still edit within the viewport, can viewport fields be marked as read-only?
  • If a user makes a change in a view port (a comment or update), do the normal triggers and notifications fire in jira core?
  • Is user/group management still in jira core (or crowd) or spread across the core and the viewport?
  • Will the viewport support plugins?
  • Will Confluence integrate with the viewport or just with jira core?

David,

Answers (off the top of my head) to your questions:

  • Notifications would have to be handled differently. You'd want them to respect permissions (only certain fields), but also URLs should go back to the viewport not the JIRA instance.
  • I would imagine that you can create as many or as few ViewPorts as you need. Each with its own set of users & permissions.
  • Mapping workflow names / states would be a long-term goal, but I imagine not in v1.
  • I hadn't imagined ViewPort fields to be read-only at a transport level (end to end), as that isn't a JIRA feature and would have to be built in ViewPort. What is the use-case?
  • All normal triggers & notifications in JIRA would fire when a ViewPort was saved.
  • User/Group management will be in JIRA, but you would select users per ViewPort (as above).
  • Plugins - v2 or later I'd imagine.
  • Confluence Integration - would be similar to the integration with normal websites. Though I'd be interested in your use-case.

We do not allow customers to edit issues. If there is a field that they need to edit, we create a workflow they can execute to change it. It would be much easier to mark all but these few fields as read-only and grant the customer edit access instead of creating individual workflows. One of these fields is a customer priority field. We allow the customer to rank the relative priority of their issues, and this is separate from our priority ranking which they cannot edit.

Another use-case is for internal users: we have fields that only our support staff are allowed to edit. So we had removed these from edit screens; create workflows with transitions screens containing those fields; and restrict those transitions to the support staff. This allows developers to edit the issues without changing those fields.

Regarding Confluence, I'd like the ability to provide our Customers with JIRA views embedded into Confluence that are restricted to just the fields they are allowed to see as defined in a viewport.

I feel like I've only scratched the surface and that viewports are just a taste of what your customers want. Unless your utlimate plan is to provide full featured field level security via viewports, you might end up frustrating everyone more by tantalizing them with something that is almost, but never quite, FLS. I think you would be better served in the long run to get the foundation of FLS correct (that is, the ability to assign permissions per field per role per project) - unless viewports will perform an end-run around re-architecting and achieve all the same functionalitly.

If you decide to implement this when do you think it will be available? I cant believe that it has taken this long for someone to come up with this soloution as the first time this issue was raised was nearly 10 years ago. I am currently evaluting JIRA and it seems the issues i am finding with it are not new issues and are still issues today.
This would at least be a good start and cover the simple cases where external clients can create and comment on issues, and can see estimates, but not actual times. I hope to see it implemented soon

Hi,
So any plans for this? I still see it in Open mode and we would still really like this functionality.
Cheers...Suan

Hey guys,

Just to give you an update on this issue - we are actively looking at building out the ability for administrators to define alternate views of JIRA!

Our current thinking is to implement "Viewport" as a paid add-on to JIRA that will let you create views that are well-suited to the needs of end users.

We are considering features that will allow administrators to:

  • Hide irrelevant fields, eg. if you want to remove time tracking from your end-user facing view, you can do that
  • Rename fields, eg. rename the "Fix Version" field to "ETA"
  • Mark fields as read-only, eg. end users cannot edit the "Fix Version" field
  • Remap workflow states, eg. instead of "Developer Escalation" you can remap the status to "In Progress" for the end user view
  • Pre-define filters to make it easy for end users to navigate lists of issues that are relevant to them, eg. "Open Issues" may be backed by JQL that returns all open issues that reported by the current user

We are mapping out some of the potential user experiences for this plugin and will be beginning development shortly. We really want to deliver iterative value, so we'll open up an Early Access Program (EAP) for the plugin as soon as practically possible so that we can get your feedback.

Cheers,

-Shihab
Sounds good - of course if the price would be relevant

And what about Announcement Banner? What you want displayed to one Viewport might be totally inappropriate for display to another Viewport.

Plus, we could hopefully move our Jira server back behind the firewall and only open a port to the external Viewport server or web pages with embedded scripts like with the Issue Collectors.

No more fields or features that external testers do not need to see, no more checking if filters, dashboards, or Rapid Boards were set to All Users by accident. Ability to focus testers on the important issue fields (less required fields than internally?), hopefully with default values (issue templates!), and being able to restrict the issue types that can be created (e.g. only Bug, Improvement, New Feature). Maybe the "developer" comments can also be solved in a more organic way than setting the security level for the comment field.

Will there be a plugin for JIRA v4, too?

Our consulting + developemnt teams use JIRA 4 intensively since 2010.
Our admin team has invested many hours in finding the ideal workflow settings.
JIRA has become an indispensible tool for us and for our customers.
We only miss the possibility of hiding time info from customers.
Our management wouldn't happily pay another $2200 for v5 above the price of the plugin.

Thanks for the input!

This is our current thinking:

  • Pricing/Licensing: We haven't yet decided on pricing. For the initial version, users of Viewport will still need to be licensed JIRA users. We will consider building out a separate licensing tier that makes sense for 'Viewport-only' users.
  • Look and Feel: we will allow admins to upload their own company logo. We are also thinking that Viewport will come with a few in-built "themes" and we will allow administrators to supply their own CSS to completely customise the interface to match their corporate style. We haven't yet thought about announcement banners per se, but admins will be able to customise the title / text / description per Viewport.
  • Security: Viewport will be a plugin to JIRA, so you won't be able to 'firewall off' access to JIRA and still have access to Viewport - they will be served off the same port. Viewport (at least in our current thinking) won't exist as a separate web app. We plan on supporting the notion of blocking off a lists or groups of users from access to JIRA so that they can only use JIRA through the Viewport UI. Would this suffice?
  • End user features: We are currently thinking that end users (viewport-only) will not have access to dashboards or rapid boards. End users will only be able to see lists of issues (filters) that the admin has defined.
  • Fields: Admins will be to define default field values in Viewport, but if you really need advanced templating for testers I'd recommend you give Bonfire a go. It specifically targets the needs of testers with sophisticated templates, test sessions and annotation tools.
  • Issue Types: Admins will be able to restrict the types of issues end users can create.
  • Developer Comments: We haven't yet decided how we will handle internal comments to end users. We have been toying with the concept of letting an end-user know that they need to take action on the request (eg. provide more information). I'd love to hear more about how you think "developer" comments should work.
  • Compatibility: our current thinking is that the plugin will be compatible with JIRA 5.0+. As much has changed between JIRA 4.x and 5.0 in terms of API compatibility, there would be quite a bit of extra effort to provide compatibility with JIRA 4.x and not all features may be backwards compatible. This is why we have decided that Viewport will be compatible with JIRA 5.0+, at least for the initial version.

• Pricing/Licensing: it's fine for us to have a V1 in 2013 that still uses regular Jira licenses and a V2 in 2014 that splits off the licensing; we want to be able to keep our 500 user Jira license for a couple of hundred internal users while still serving several thousand external viewport testers; currently, external testers keep eating up our licenses even if they only log in once and never enter an issue
  • Security: you are right, I also see viewport V1/2 as a plugin so we need an external URL for the server like with the issues collectors; maybe for V3 this could be rethought as a simple additional Jetty based server; blocking of viewport users from regular Jira would be great to have already in V1, can you model this even while still sharing the regular user licenses as per above? I guess a new global permission would suffice
  • Look and Feel: sounds sufficient from our side; I like the idea of having a free form text field at the top of the form like in the issue collectors
  • End user features: perfect! was just wondering if you assign viewport users to project roles or create one viewport form per project like an issue collector; but using filters and assigning viewport users to them sounds quite easy and flexible; will these users then have the right to enter new issues for all projects that are contained in those filters?
  • Fields: default values for custom and system fields would already be a great plus compared to Jira today! would be sufficient for us to e.g. pre-set the current Affects Version for the beta testers and maybe a Component
    [I can see that you want to keep templates as an exclusive Bonfire feature; if you only added a full featured client version of Bonfire that can take screenshots off the screen and not only inside the browser, the tool would be more interesting for developers of fat apps]
  • Issue Types: perfect!
  • Compatibility: 5.0+ is fine for us
  • Developer Comments: it's a tough one! I just know that my users always ask me why they need to hide comments away, and I tell them to not write anything that a beta tester should not read but in the end, developers must be able to talk internally without having to bother with setting the security each time; so maybe add a new viewport comment field to Jira and try to remove the Comment field security in the long run? or default the security of Comment to all users of the project except viewport users?

I agree with Susan and Ahmad, specifically on workflow and issue groups (issue level security). Indeed, I forgot in my points above that we are also customizing our workflow in a way that external users can close and reopen their own reported issues. Would be nice if this could work implicitly for viewport users in the future. Plus, we are using a quite complicated automated way to set security levels so that external users can only see issue of other external users.

So we would need multiple 'viewport' groups?

I think we should break away from the JIRA thinking patterns ...

Markus, your "extreme" scenario could be a straight forward implementation with ViewPort:

  • Three issues categories on the screen in ViewPort for a ViewPort user: Issues ...
    • I have reported or assigned to
    • I'm participating in
    • I'm viewing / watching

  • Create JIRA filters (using all the known features) to get a subset of issues a ViewPort user (or group of ViewPort users)
    1. can view
    2. view and comment on
    3. view, comment and edit
    4. view, comment, edit and do workflow transitions

  • Based on this filters, ViewPort controls the actions/permissions of the users

So,

  • beta testers could see internal issues because you created a filter for the internal issues and assigned it as "viewable by ViewPoint group"
  • end users can see only public issues because you created a filter for issues marked as public
  • and beta testers can see the issues they have reported
  • or issues they have to process because your team provided feedback (and assigned it to them)

With ViewPort we will get rid of the "field-level security" issues because ViewPort can start to limit the fields on the minimum needed to be shown, or even implement it's own mechanisms to decide if a field is viewable, edit etc.

What about this approach for the beginning?

  1. JIRA:
    • Please provide an option to define the default role or group for a comment on a per-project level, e.g. group "internal users" or a role only visible to internal users
      • This would enable JIRA users (= non ViewPort users) to discuss an issue without spare a thought about the proper "Viewable by" setting e.g. because it not visible for (ViewPort) users
      • So having the option to define a default security level for JIRA comments is a good idea anyway
    • Now there must be a role (not technically speaking) within ViewPort who is able to decided on a per comment level if it's visible to ViewPort users or not

  2. or
    • JIRA is able to provide a label field on a per-comment level
      • labels for comments can be enabled on a per project level
      • with default labels pre-assigned (e.g. non-public)
      • And if you want to share it a comment with a ViewPort user, you have to assign the proper label
      • And now we can start to use the filter approach I outlined in my last comment: if filter matches, comment is visible for the ViewPort user (or group of ViewPort users)
  3. ViewPort:
    • User can post a comment but can not decide a group or role level about "Viewable by" (too complex)
    • If view port would have the categories I suggested - Issues ...
      • a) ... I have reported or assigned to
      • b) ... I'm participating in
      • c) ... I'm viewing / watching
        than we could ...
  4. .. define which label would be assigned to which category regarding the visibility of comments, e.g.
      • a) only viewable by JIRA users, not shared with any ViewPort users
      • b) viewable by all users who participating in this issue
      • c) N/A (because if you comment on an issue, it would move to the category b) "... I'm participating in")

Hey guys,

Thanks for your thoughts on the issue!

Viewport is about tailoring the JIRA experience for users that need to create and track their request. The main goal of Viewport is to make it possible for administrators to define an "outsider" or "end user" class of users on a project and simplify the interaction the end users have with JIRA - from the user interface through to email notifications.

We're trying to help teams do more with JIRA - IT helpdesk requests, finance approvals, HR processes and even office administration can be mapped to JIRA projects with appropriate issue types and workflows. Viewport enables these teams to provide an easy way for their end users to create and track their requests so that the teams servicing the requests can use the power of JIRA to manage the issues.

One of the features of Viewport that we're planning on providing is the ability to hide internal fields from the view of "outsiders" or "end users" - fields like time tracking. JRA-1330 is about hiding fields from every possible spot in JIRA for a certain class of users, whereas with Viewport, end users can be restricted to only have access to JIRA through the Viewport interface - they will not have access to JIRA features such as JQL searching or dashboards.

We do plan on delivering value incrementally with an MVP first. Many of the aspects of Viewport are interrelated so it's not possible for us to ship the ability to "hide time-tracking" without some of the other capabilities. If you would like to get involved in the early access program for Viewport and try out early builds of the plugin, please sign up on www.atlassian.com/viewport - we'll be reaching out to those that have signed up once we're closer to an early milestone of Viewport.

Cheers,

-Shihab

Hey,

Viewport will allow you to tailor an interface to JIRA that encourages your end users to create, view and collaborate on requests, while your internal teams take advantage of the full power of JIRA to process these issues.

The Viewport interface has been designed from the ground up with the aim to provide an optimal experience for users - and as it is a distinct interface to JIRA, we are able to hide fields, rename fields, re-map statuses and the like.

AM, we believe that Viewport will actually make use cases such as using JIRA as a support system even more appealing as it will allow admins tailor JIRA to sound more like a support system.

  • Hide fields that don't make sense to those that are making requests or data that you don't want to reveal to them, like time tracking, the issue assignee, or issue labels
  • Instead of "Summary" you will be able do ask your users to "Describe the problem you are experiencing"
  • You will be able to add custom descriptions to fields and link out external systems or documentation
  • You can present clear calls to action for your end user, so you might have "Support Ticket" as your issue type, but create issue templates for "Report a system fault", "Request a password reset", etc and have the correct issue information pre-populated for your support team.
  • You could internally have statuses such as "Waiting for Developer" but still present an "In Progress" status for your customer.

We think Viewport will enable you to craft solutions like this for a variety of use cases including customer support, internal IT service desk, change management - as well as those outside of software development like purchase order approvals and office admin requests.

Sascha Meyer/Normand Carbonneau: If your QA team or your customers/clients do really need full access to JIRA and features like full JQL searching, dashboards, rapid boards or reports - but you just need to hide a few fields from them in all possible places in JIRA - then unfortunately Viewport will not solve this problem in the near term.

Cheers,

-Shihab

Atlassian Status as of 26 February 2014

"Viewports" was a concept we explored that could provide the ability for admins to partition the view of a ticket into "end users" and "insiders". The intention was to allow admins to tailor an interface to JIRA that encourages end users to create, view and collaborate on requests, while your internal teams take advantage of the full power of JIRA to process these issues. We had hoped that this solution would also help customers who wanted to hide time tracking fields as per JRA-2364 (Hide Time Tracking estimates from certain users).

Your feedback on Viewport and the specific needs for hiding time tracking made it clear that generic Viewport wasn't the best way to solve customers' problems. There were two very different use cases:
1) Using JIRA to power their service desk operations. This idea evolved into JIRA Service Desk.
2) Hiding time tracking fields (usually because external consultants or customers were collaborating in JIRA, but everything except time tracking information)

Service Desk:
One of the key parts of JIRA Service Desk is the Customer Portal, which implements much of the original concepts of Viewport, but tailored for the service desk use case. Using the Customer Portal you can build customer / end-user oriented views of issue types - you can hide fields, rename fields, re-map workflow statuses. You can effectively give a different view of your issue to different audiences. With the recent release of JIRA Service Desk 1.2, you can also lock out your Customer Portal users from being able to log in to JIRA altogether.

If you've been waiting for "Viewports", I recommend you give JIRA Service Desk a try. Service Desk is much more than what Viewport started out as - there are queues, reports, service level agreements, knowledge base integration and much more in development.

At this stage, we will close off this issue, as we will unlikely revisit shipping "Viewports" as originally described in this issue. Thank you to everyone who has contributed to this issue.

Time Tracking:
A deeper look into time tracking with customers and their use cases revealed that just hiding the standard JIRA time tracking fields from the UI would not be enough. They needed to be inaccessible through REST APIs, change history, and a number of other areas. There were other fields that customers needed hidden that were "related" to time tracking. So a simple solution of hiding time tracking from View Issue would still be expensive to develop, add more complexity to JIRA, and not actually solve the full problem. Due to this, at this time we are leaving JRA-2364 closed.

Edwin Wong
JIRA Service Desk Product Manager
