Anders, Normand, Peter, Bernhard, Jean-Jacques, Patrick,

Thanks for your comments. I can appreciate that you may be disappointed the closure of this issue. Making decisions like these are always difficult for us, and definitely not a part of the job that we enjoy. If we had an infinite amount of capacity, we would love to do every feature request in this tracker. However, the reality is that we are always constrained to balance the different competing priorities of the product.

At this stage, we are closing this issue because we cannot see that this issue will resolved in our foreseeable future given other priorities. We believe being up front and clear about this is a better embodiment of our values than to keep this request open.

As for workarounds to hide time tracking information, there is the Field Security Plugin developed by Quisapps available in the marketplace that can hide time tracking information (and custom fields).

Edwin Wong
JIRA Service Desk Product Manager

Hi Edwin, thanks for the answer regarding the Field Security Plugin, but once again, it seems that Atlassian is ignoring On-Demand customers who are paying several thousands of dollars per year, but still miss a critical functionality which is being able to hide time tracking. As long as we don't have this feature, we cannot work with our customers in JIRA or JIRA Agile, which is, by the way, the exact opposite of how we need to work in Agile... The customer must be part of the team.

So, how can we work with your product then??

Hello,
Is there finally hope to solve a long awaited feature?
Hiding "time tracking fields" in Jira for external users is a major request for many Jira users.

I see that a new plugin has been made available for the download instance: https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.gebsun.plugins.jira.hidetimetracking .

This ability has been requested for more than 10 years ago (check the history of related issues to time tracking). Jira (Atlassian) came up with, for sure, many great features but never solved the real need.

I'm convinced, if this plugin works as described, this would be appreciated by many many Jira users.

Looking forward to the quick responsiveness of Jira Team to make this plugin available in "on demand".

Cheers

Jean-Jacques, I wouldn't count on it. They've been coming up with excuses for 10 years; that should tell you how much they value this feature.
You have a few options:

  • Switch from ondemand to onpremise and get a plugin. Of course this comes with all the headache and cost that made you go for ondemand in the first place, so not an option.
  • Double-book keeping; create two versions of each project, one internal and one external. Lots of extra admin overhead so no real option.
  • Don't let customers in Jira. They will have less visibility and your team will have to copy all their comments from email to Jira. No real option.
  • That leaves... find another solution and leave Jira behind.
@Jean-Jacques Courtens: Thank you. I will check out the plugin. Hope it will fit our needs.

@Ronald Vallenduuk...thanks for your reply.
You indeed pointed out the different options and we looked/tried all of them.
Leaving Jira behind is indeed an option, all the others are not. But I must also say, on a positive note, we've a lot of satisfaction with other Jira features and Jira in general with Confluence, Bit Bucket and so on. But this "hide time tracking fields" is indeed the cause of lots of frustration on our side. Did you find another solution?

We're in the same boat. There's a lot of things we like about Jira and we haven't found a replacement.
The need to hide time tracking doesn't affect all our projects so for the moment we're putting up with the missing functionality.

@Ronald, we're indeed in the same boat and facing exactly the same situation.
Let's hope that Atlassian (Jira) will surprise us by quickly enabling this long awaited plugin. Just want to stay positive after all.

@Jean-Jacques I would advise you against using this new plugin at all in its current state. It just seems to work, but actually everything is still visible in change history, activity streams etc etc.

@Alexander: Many thanks for the info. It's indeed possible that this plugin is still early stage and that it does not yet cover all aspects.
In fact, this type of plugin was expected to be developed by Atlassian (Jira) in order to provide a solution for "hiding time tracking fields". It's a pity this has to be performed by a third party.

Hello guys,

The mentioned Hide Time Tracking plugin is now a mature product and time tracking information is not visible in JIRA UI (for users without 'work on issues' permission).
In case of any problems you can raise an issue at https://gebsun.atlassian.net/browse/HTT

Regards,
Gebsun

@Atlassian
No matter what we use JIRA for, there are almost always two parties involved. Service provider and service consumer (or customer). When there is more than one party, there will always be some information that needs to be hid from customer. Service Desk is a solution that solves only a small portion of this problem. The need to hide some fields from some users in the conventional JIRA interface is critical.

The initial idea of viewports was a promising one yet you decided not to implement it. Believe me guys, Service Desk can not meet those needs. You say it is very hard to implement this feature since it would require large portions of JIRA to be rewritten. You know what: You should start immediately!!!

JIRA is moving to an upper league these days. We, as a partner, are positioning JIRA for all kinds of needs: Request management, project & portfolio management, service desk, audits, etc... you name it. Believe me when I say this feature is needed desparately. This is more important than Service Desk or Portfolio. There is no version of future that JIRA can go on without this feature forever. Sooner or later you will have to implement this. The sooner it is done the less damage. (We are currently implementing a very large scale Atlassian project and we suffered a lot because of this. I can not put enough emphasis on how important this is.)

Today another user asked for this feature. They want to use JIRA but want different teams to see different fields.
Just for you to know.
I need this desperately! I don't think all users need to see time tracking.

item.title: [CONF-3191] Easily create a copy of an entire space
item.description:
It'd be really very handy to be able to duplicate a space. Export/import only works on 1 space I think (it seems to have lots of integer ids in there so I dare not try exporting, twiddling things and reimporting).

What would be really nice would be a 'copy space' option where you can duplicate an entire space as a different name/key.

e.g. setting up projects at codehaus; it'd be good to use an existing space as a base, then copy the entire thing, then after that either export/import to search/replace, or just manually modify pages after that.
item.summary: Easily create a copy of an entire space

status.description: Issue is open and has not yet been accepted by Atlassian.

comments.comment: This seems to be a duplicate of CONF-2814 and related to CONF-2931.

Yes, this would be an incredibly useful feature. I'm glad that there is at least some Page-Copy functionality in 2.0, but there are definately additional useful Copy-related features that could be added.

Space copy, during which you could specify whether you want to just grab Pages + attachments, or limit the copy in other ways. For instance, I may want to just create a duplicate Space with permissions setup. Or a Space with all pages + content + attachments, but no comments or news or mail.

Another useful thing would be an option to copy a page, but at the same time copy all decendant pages beneath it. This would require a bit more work, as a UI of some sort for creating unique new page names would be implemented. Another option would be a choice to append some text to the start or end of each page title, like "new" or "copy of."

along this line, perhaps deleteing an entire tree of pages from the top level. Maybe these should be moved to a new issue...

Agree totally. There should be a way to clone a whole space easily, with a way to specify a group for security as well.

If I have a new customer called ACME, I want to:

  • Create a project space from my templated space structure
  • Make a group called ACME and assign some default permission set to the new project space

That would be really nice.

Kind regards,
Rick

There are two distinct feature requests open relating to copying space content.

  • CONF-3191 will allow you to copy all pages, news and comments in a space, including space themes and colour schemes. It cannot be used to copy part of a space only.
  • CONF-2814 to copy any hierarchy of pages easily to another existing space.

Please be sure to vote towards the issue/s that most closely matches your needs.

David Soul

This would be extremely useful to me. I regularly need to snapshot a space and make a copy of it available under a different spacename. The export/import workaround is a total hack that I shouldn't have to do. Confluence should do it for me.
not to mention that the hack is really rather broken as we found out recently (and yes have notified Atlassian of it).
The ability to copy a space comes up frequently in customer requests, such as when setting up new projects. Refer to sales@atlassian.com email exchange with housevalues.com for an example

Cloning a space would be an excellent feature that will be very useful for companies like ours that create the same structure for our various clients. This feature should have the option of copying or not copying the attachment document(s)>

I wrote a plugin to attempt this feature over a couple of shipit days: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFEXT/Copy+Space+Plugin
It's not perfect but it will be useful to some of you. Although not formally tested, we have been using it to archive documentation spaces on confluence.atlassian.com for about 8 months. My apologies for not updating the issue earlier.

It would be great to have a reliable and non-beta way of doing this. I'm using the copy-space plugin to copy live content into a development space, but it makes me nervous when I'm using kit which is labelled "beta" and "may break" so loudly.

This would be a useful feature; since Don has created a plugin: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFEXT/Copy+Space+Plugin - we may be able to make this a supported plugin depending on how comprehensive it is. This work would take about 2-3 weeks if scheduled. We will consider this a medium priority against other higher voted feature requests and try to get it in a release within the next year.

If you're interested to know how we decide on which features to implement, please read this:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DEV/Implementation+of+New+Features+and+Improvements

My company has been using the copy space plugin for about 6 months now as a way to to have a way to create new spaces from a "template" space; but note these template spaces are very simple and don't use any special plugins (just a few standard macros). I've notice one annoying bug in that in that some pages in the copied space say created by "Anonymous", but other than that it works well.

I vote for productizing/supporting the copy space plugin.

Copying a space has been a key requirement for one of my clients. Unfortunately because the Copy Space Plugin isn't supported, and sometimes lags behind in compatibility with newly released versions of Confluence, I'm faced with no support for the plugin and having to hold back on upgrading Confluence until the Copy Space Plugin catches up.

The copy space plugin works well.
If it has issues then those should be addressed but not here. Atlassian this issue should be marked as resolved in my opinion. Not doing so is a bit confusing because it looks like this feature is not available when it is so.

If someone actually needs the plugin supported as a requirement my opinion is that that should be a separate issue.

Most of the plugins do work from Confluence version to version, but it can be confusing to users when the plugins are not marked as compatible. I think "not compatible" needs to be split out into "not comaptable" AND "not tested".

The Copy Space plugin has a number of limitations, but is the perhaps the best work around in most cases.

The limitation which has the most impact on our usage is its requirement that the person making the copy have admin rights. We let everybody create new spaces, but we do not let everybody have admin rights. There's no reason why someone who can view/read a Space and can create new Spaces, should not be able to copy that Space.

I think this limitation is minor.
Copying an entire space is an operation which can be abused, and is not expected to happen a lot.
In case of need you can submit a request to admins to do it for you.

It would be very good to have this plugin in our studio.

How would copying an entire space which you already can view be abused? As user with that ability and the ability to create a new space could still copy the pages one at a time.

Copying an entire space simply saves a huge amount of employee work time.

The number of users of your installation must be very small compared to the number of users I have. We create a new space, which should be copied from an existing template, for every new project we start, plus other spaces for non-project work. We're a contracting company, so we do many new projects each year.

Requesting the admins do this work wastes a tremendous amount of time, both for the project managers who want to get on with their work and create their spaces, and for the admins, who are few in number and have other full-time jobs to manage. JIRA and Confluence are high-quality, powerful products that empower individuals; they should not require (and do not, in our practice) hiring several full time admins to simply manage them on a daily basis.

Hi Chris,

I'll play Devils advocate...

Imagine I could view the space, but admins of the space had restricted pages.

Now I copy that space, I become space admin of the copied space, I can now see all the restricted areas.

Giving someone a "space copy" permission, would effectively give them space admin rights to view an entire space they wouldn't have normally been able to view.

If you want users who can view a space to be able to copy it, the copying process would either have to fail on finding any restrictions in the space, or go through the entire space checking the restrictions of every page and selectively copying it based on if the user copying the space could actually see it or not. Whilst also leaving all permissions in place to prevent other users accessing this new space copy to see pages they previously couldn't see in the original.
one vote from me

@Steve Daniels:

JIRA should make things possible. The organization should come with its restrictions.

Regarding copy permissions - i think it's an organizational policy.
JIRA's work is to make things possible and safe. Not to police the users.
Every organization should maintain it's own policy according to it's own needs.
Some organizations would rather openness (and may chose to install the plugin) and others not.

I'll explain

Give one a permission to clone a space - he can will clone whatever he's privileged to see.
"Problem" solved.

So far so good. Now for privileges:

The copied space should have no publish permissions, and the admin of the new space should actively publish his work.
If somebody publishes confidential materials - it's to be handled by the organization's policy, not by JIRA.

If technically cloning a page with it's original permissions is easier, I can live with that, however, I still think that a cloned page should not inherit permissions, unless maybe explicitly asked to using some checkbox or anything.

A far fetched throw - a more conclusive solution

I could agree that a more elegant solution will be an import tool that selects a source space and a target space (that could create new space for a target), presents a source tree of all what the user can see where every item features two checkboxes and two links:

  • link : name of the document - opens in a nother popup/tab/preview area the document itself
  • checkbox 1: selects the item and it's siblings for clone, (similar to the installation wizards, where a checkbox in the tree checks/unchecks its siblings as well),
  • checkbox 2: enables whenever the 1st checkbox is selected - for cloning permissions.
  • link : opens the active permissions of the source document

However, I doubt if we'll ever get that. Maybe a specific new plugin can be written for it, however, I'm afraid I'm not the man to do it

One step further would be on the permission-preview - to manage the permissions for the new clone. But that's an extra-cool luxury...
One more vote on making it possible to easily rename or copy a space via the Confluence UI.
Huge need for this in my shop.

I am actually creating a lot of documentation in Confluence. I am trying to apply the same pattern than Atlassian for Jira documentation, meaning that I create a new space for a new version.
But it seems that we can't copy an entire space?
For example, if I have a Space MySpace_V10, and I want a new space named MySpace_V11, with all the same content that I only have to edit to reflect the changes of V11, how can I do that?
Please don' tell me that I have to manually copy hundred of pages manually. If this is the case, Confluence is of no use for our organization.
Confluence should be a tool, not an additional work load. Please always keep this in mind when you decide which new feature you will deliver in the next version.

Thanks, Normand

I used the steps outlined here as a guide:

http://spicysquid.blogspot.com/2008/09/how-to-copy-confluence-space.html

Since I have Atlassian OnDemand, I can't install the Copy Space Plugin. It would be great in Atlassian just made that one of the available plugins until they come up with a real solution. Instead I export the space (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Exporting+Confluence+Pages+and+Spaces+to+XML), open the entities.xml in Notepad, do a find/replace on the space name and the space key, replacing with my new name/key, and then I 'restore' the space (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Restoring+a+Space).

There are some gotchas, such as if you copy/paste internal links or images they will remain linked to the old document, which is a problem... and a big problem if your copy has broader privileges than the original.

I copy spaces in order to issue public versioned documentation for our software, so what I would REALLY want is to replicate what Atlassian does with their own documentation (see the version blurb at the top of those documentation links above, for example).

we end up creating a new documentation trea for each new project we start (we start a new project) every couple of weeks - it would be great if we would just clone a default space with the template hierarchy already built

Took a look at the plugin, however imo this is a must have for the product.
Copy should include 'relative' links to the same Wiki. If there are any 'restricted' pages, these should be for Confluence admins only. Yes: this would not be complete or perfect. However: current 'workarounds' as present in the product (copy pages one at a time) or workarounds (export - import) or the plugin (not supported, also an upgrade hazard) are not the solution.

You have a great product, this would make it so much more useful.

Hendrik
This is definitely one we need too, it will help us to create a new version of our documentation each time we do a software release.

+1 and for Ondemand too. Its a shame that 6 years on this has not been picked up because any org that uses Jira and confluence to manage multiple products / websites etc will most probably want to have a templated structure for spaces as a starting point. Having to copy and move these one by one is very resource intensive and in some respects defeats the purpose of a product like this. This should not be a difficult feature to implement.
+1 for OnDemand. It's pretty standard documentation functionality. 7 years since the original request? Wow. At least it makes me feel good about our dev cycles
+1 for OnDemand!
+1 for OnDemand

if your primary use case for copying pages is to archive content, then Archiving Plugin takes care of the whole process for you automatically. if you primary use case is different, it still may be an option to check. why?

what it does in the background is that it creates an archive space for each live space, and copies the expired content to the archive space.

to solve your original problem: you can mark your whole source space as expired, run the archiving job, then make the archive space active again, and voila, the original space is duplicated! (the plugin copies the page hierarchy selectively, comments, attachments and labels.)

it was developed as a lean solution for content lifecycle management, so it may be a little too much for just a "copy page set" plugin, but I wanted to let you know that there are other options.

see the Archiving Plugin documentation
+1 for onDemand
+1 for onDemand
+1 for OnDemand
+1 for OnDemand
+1 for OnDemand
+1 for OnDemand
I see this is still unassigned, come Atlassian listen to your customers. Its a major major gap in the product. How many more +1's votes do you need to take notice
+1 for OnDemand
+1 for OnDemand

It seems like Atlassians internal technical writers have recognized the absolute need for a copy space functionality and are referring to the Copy space add-on in articles outlining best practices for tech writing in Confluence (https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Managing+the+Life+Cycle+of+your+Technical+Documentation). In light of this it is rather confusing that the OnDemand version doesn't have this functionality. Please fix!
Get on it! Since 2005??

Meanwhile you can use this method. It is actually quite simple and I have used it to replicate dozens of spaces:

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONF34/Copy+Or+Rename+A+Space

If you find any limitations to it, please let me know

@atlassian, when can we expect such a feature in confluence on demand? In order to manage documentation versions, we need to be able to copy an existing space as a new space.
Without this feature we're very limited in confluence. We try to setup jira, agile, confluence, service desk,...in order to manage development tasks, request from the customers...in one word to have all activities fully integrated in one environment!

Looking at the history of this request (since 2009 and we're in 2014!!!!!) it seems that we're facing the same issue as with the request related to hiding the time tracking fields (open since more than 10 years!!!!).

What we do not understand, is that this plugin "copy space" is available for the "download" version since 2007-09 (beta), has been downloaded more than 23000 times and has been developed by Atlassian developers. After so many years, we believe we could expect a stable version for "demand".

This is yet another major bottleneck we are encountering in order to use Atlassian as sole product for our internal/external communication.

Our frustration, is that this feature does not seems to be a complex feature, but without it we're facing major, complex and time driven work arounds.

When will you be able to solve this once and for all?

@Jean-Jacques Courtens have you tried this? https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONF34/Copy+Or+Rename+A+Space

In our case, we created a "template" space with permissions per group or role and whenever we have a new project we follow the procedure on the link above

@asael, thx for your feedback. i understand that we can perform a copy of a space with a manual procedure (long, complex and with a high risk of mistakes).
We've multiple documentation spaces (several products) to maintain and manage their versions.
The frustration, is that there is already since several years a plugin for the "download" version of confluence which performs all these actions in a few clicks and that this plugin is still not available for the "on demand" version of confluence.

we are also desperately in need of this in OnDemand - everytime we start a new a project we have to copy all kinds standard structure and boiler plate documentation manually - and guess what? - as its manual it never gets done properly

What we have done to get around this is to use the XML-RPC API to create new spaces. We also use it for bulk search and replace and many other things.Once you create a new empty space you can use getPage() (on the space to be copied) and storePage() to store the pages in the new space.

https://developer.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Remote+Confluence+Methods

-Greg

I too manage product documentation using Confluence (in house) and have the same issue with regard to cloing spaces - I do this routinely once a major/minor version has shipped. The Copy Space Plugin does work, but its drawback is that it does not retain any page history... The other complex manual method works sometimes and other times doesn't and if it does, it always causes my Confluence admins all sorts of headaches. They hate me requesting to clone a space.... a built in GUI option for Confluence admins would be so useful.....
As an Ondemand user, I can't use the plugin. Adding my vote to this functionality. Please move forward with this ASAP

My previous instance of Confluence was a downloaded server version & it had the 'WONDERFUL' ability to copy spaces. My current instances (for new companies) are both on-demand and its really frustrating to lose a feature i relied on so heavily.

Please complete ASAP

Would be nice to have it in 5.6.3 since Copy Space Plugin is supposedly "Incompatible" it still works as far as I know...

Please create us an alternative or complete it.

For OnDemand users I noticed this recently: https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/ac-copy-space
We may be moving some doc to OnDemand so I'd be interested if anyone knows if it works? It says it is limited to 50 pages but that they can increase this limit...

Hi James,

The limit of pages for a single copy is actually 500. We developed it originally with 50 but shortly thereafter increased it to 500. However the documentation lagged behind. I have fixed the documentation and wanted to let you know the limit IS 500 pages currently.

Copy Space OnDemand

Cheers,
Brendan
Copy Space did not work for me in 5.6.5. The command is there but nothing happens. How many votes does it take before Atlassian fixes something?
In order to control documentation versions, we need to be able to copy an existing space as a new space.
Approaching an upgrade to 5.7. This is the only add-on that we rely on that will not be compatible.

We are finding that creating a 'reference' space that we can use to inflate a project would be a great productivity boost. We want to use the tools uniformly across projects. Item that add hours to the setup for a project that is only 40-80 hours of work really cuts into the margins. And not doing it undermines the the drive to have a culture of using this every time.

We found that on Confluence Cloud instances with JIRA Cloud, the copy of an entire Space can be done by linking the new space to a JIRA Project.

On JIRA & Confluence Cloud instances, Space imports can be linked to JIRA Projects. The process changes the Space KEY on the export file, to the JIRA Project KEY.

Export the Space and import it by linking it to a new JIRA Project with the new desired KEY:

  1. In JIRA create a new project without a Confluence Space linked to it.
  2. On Confluence, go to Space -> Space Tools -> Content Tools -> Export -> XML -> Next -> Full Export -> Export Space and export the target space as XML including attachments.
  3. Download the export
  4. Go to Import Spaces
  5. Select the Export and the option to link the Space import to the JIRA project created on step 1
  6. Import Space

Cheers

I'm not sure if this is the correct issue for this, but what is being done to address the lag in the COPY SPACE PLUG-IN catching up with confluence releases? We rely totally on this plug-in working for our technical documentation wiki, but the newest version it is 'compatible with is v5.5.7. Can Atlassian please advise, or provide an alternative that a non-technical user can easily utilise? thanks

Helen Gosper please note that the Atlassian Labs Copy Space Plugin is unsupported. As such, we do not test it against each new Confluence release, and the compatibility information on Marketplace reflects that.

I installed it onto a test instance of 5.8 and performed some very quick testing. I found that it does not correctly handle inline comments (introduced in Confluence 5.7) - if you copy a space containing inline comments they will be converted to regular page comments. If you don't use inline comments in your technical documentation then this won't be an issue for you, and everything else seemed to work ok. You should perform your own due diligence testing before using it on a production instance.

Alternatives are available to you on Marketplace, such as Copy Page Tree by Artemis Software. This is a commercial add-on, and you can expect regular updates and support for new releases of Confluence. It is currently marked as compatible with Confluence versions 4.1 through to 5.8.5.

Thanks Mark for quick response. We don't use inline comments in our technical documentation. I've also done some testing on 5.8.5 and it appears to work, although it remains a concern as to whether I take that chance or not. The Copy Page Tree seems a lot more work. Just out of interest, are there any plans to either support the Copy Space Plugin, or to develop a replacement for it?
No plans, AFAIK.

that's exactly what we're missing right now.

It should be possible to create an template space with an default page structure. layout and content. It should be possible to copy easily copy the template. It would be nice if you could choose wheather the permissions are also copied or not.
Open Feature request since 10 years. Amazing. It seems to be that you really have a ear for your customers need

Hi everybody,
it just occurred to me that I should make aware the good people on this thread that the heat is on on Support the Copy Space Plugin!

Please support us with your comments there!
I swore I won't give up until we got a solution and woke up the management to listen to our often decade-old problems.
After two calls to EMEA support I guess they realized I´m serious and since then I´m in contact and I know what´s going on behind the scenes.

Please don´t let it stall now! Comment on Support the Copy Space Plugin!

To repeat it here:
EMEA support number is +31 20 796 0060

According to Martin:
International Contact Hotlines:
AU (Headquarter) Number: +61 2 9262 1443
US Number: +1 415 701 1110

Thanks
G.

Hi everyone,

Thanks for your helpful feedback on this ticket. On behalf of the Confluence team please accept our apologies for allowing this issue to remain open for so long without a formal response.

We're looking into this issue as part of a response to the related issue "CONF-14198 Support the Copy Space Plugin". I've posted a longer response on that issue and will shortly follow with a survey to obtain your feedback on the CONF-14198 thread.

Thank you for your long-standing interest and feedback on this issue.

Matt

Matthew Lawrence [Atlassian] nice try to de-prioritize the issue from ~440 to ~180 votes by shifting the view? You really should flip this to not fake your own reports in a customer unwilling way. this #3191 is much more older than #14198 too ... but just a note on how a JIRA customer see how you are working with JIRA yourself: That brings me back to feature Request: Merge Votes when closing as Dup JRA-3731

I have to agree with Marcel Trautwein. My personal user story is that I want to create a copy of a space. Wherever you want to place that in your codebase is not of interest to me. So to me the CONF-14198 is just an implementation detail of the real issue. Please keep us informed, when you have a solution going for CONF-3191.

item.title: [JRA-2364] Hide Time Tracking estimates from certain users (e.g. customers)
item.description:
Today everybody can see time estimates made on an issue. It would be nice if it was possible (for example via the permission scheme) to determine who should be able see them.

An idea to the level of permissions could be:

  • Edit others time estimates
  • Add/Edit own time estimates
  • View time estimates

This could also help another issue: That an administrator maybe doesn't want to enable time tracking on all projects. With the above solution the administrator can just choose not to set any Time Tracking permissions on the projects that shouldn't use Time Tracking.

/watson
item.summary: Hide Time Tracking estimates from certain users (e.g. customers)

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: If this feature is going to be added, could it be generalized to control the visibility of other fields (including custom fields) for specific groups of users?

I propose to have a specific permission to view the work log as well as any actual times. This would be internal (dev team) information only.

The time estimates on the other hand I consider information for the issue originator, helping him decide whether it's worth doing.

Hi,

I agree that it is worthwhile the customer being able to view the estimate, but it makes no sense that they can edit the estimate.

Surely only somebody with 'Work on issues' permission should be able to enter/edit the estimates? The current behaviour in this particular area seems like a bug to me...

Cheers,

Mike

Until this improvement is implemented, a workaround is to add <webwork:if> tags around JSP blocks displaying time tracking info (or edit links).

Eg, in viewissue.jsp, around line 31:

<webwork:if test="remoteUser/groups/contains('jira-developers') == true">
.... // block displaying time estimate
</webwork:if>

The places that we need to hide this appear to be:

  • emails
  • issue navigator
  • view issue
  • edit issue ?
  • hide the work log reports

Any others that I have missed?

I don't think that you missed anything. I've just tried to write in more details where time tracking fields and estimates should be hidden.

Email notifications:
------------------------------------------------------------------------
In the bottom of every notification email there is an issue summary. Here the 3 fields: Original Estimate, Time Spent and Remaining should be hidden.

When work is logged, "Work Logged" emails is send. It is already possible to control who should receive these via the Work Logged On Issue notification event. But JIRA should also look to see if the user has Time Tracking permissions.

========================================================================
Issue Navigator:
------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is possible to configure your Issue Navigator and add the 3 columns Current Estimate, Original Estimate and Time Spent. This should still be possible but on the projects where the user does not have Time Tracking permissions they should just be empty (or displaying a text like "N/A", "Hidden" or just be grey).

========================================================================
View Issue:
------------------------------------------------------------------------
When viewing an issue the 3 fields Original Time Estimated, Estimated Time Remaining and Total Time Spent are displayed just above the file attachments. These should just be hidden.

The "Work Log" should also be hidden.

The "Change History" and "All" should have some kind of filter not displaying time tracking changes.

========================================================================
Edit Issue:
------------------------------------------------------------------------
When editing an issue it should not be possible to see or change the time tracking fields. If a user with edit permissions but no Time Tracking permissions edited an issue, the time tracking fields should just be left as they where before the user edited the issue (=No change).

========================================================================
Work Log Reports:
------------------------------------------------------------------------
These should of cause also be hidden.

Btw: The temporary solution with editing the .jsp and .vm files to manually filter out time tracking for certain users did not help.

By editing .jsp and .vm files I found that it was almost possible to hide Time Tracking from certain users. The only two places I could not hide them was: The Issue Navigator (when displaying the 3 time tracking columns) and the when viewing an issue (notes in the "All" and "Change History" pages).

Second it should be mentioned that if the user not allowed to see the time tracking estimates where a bit of a hacker it would not be a problem for him to view for example the Work Log reports (because I only was hiding the links to the reports - not the reports themselves).

I think this is an important point, if customers have access to JIRA. Perhaps you could tie it to
the "Work On Issues" Permission. For example you could simply add to the
viewIssue.jsp

<webwork:if test="@fieldVisibility/fieldHidden(., 'timetracking', ../string('type')) == false && hasIssuePermission('work', /issue) == true">
<jsp:include page="/includes/panels/issue/view_timetracking.jsp" />
</webwork:if>

I know have to change it in many more jsps like tabs.jsp and so on.(limit the tabs to comment tab as you can see time tracking fields in all tabs except for "comment").Preset Reports and many more...

Also everywhere where
<webwork:if test="applicationProperties/option('jira.option.timetracking') == true">
is asked I could add the Permission Condition.

This all could easily be achieved but where I have to change the source code? I would try implement it for our company, as it is an important point for us.

Thanks,

Philip

Estimates:

  • View own time estimates

Worklog/Time Spent:

  • Edit others worklog/recorded time

Hi folks!

I am Max Weißböck's collegue slash hacker and here is our complete approach to hiding time tracking for certain users while it is enabled for others. Our approach is not generic, it is not complete, it is not perfect and definitely improvable but it is exactly what we most desperatley needed at the moment and what was the easiest to accomplish. We decided to publish our solution to the community.

But first, let me say a few angry words. This issue is open for 4 3/4 years, many people and companies hunger for a solution - for ANY solution - and all you say is "there are a number of other improvements that are more popular than this one, and therefore we will look at implementing them first"? Come on! Just tell us that you - as everyone else of us - have not the slightest idea of how to correctly solve this issue in ANY way and in proper time. Do not lie to your paying customers!

Here is our solution. all you have to do is to replace the original jsps and vms with ours (in the attached HideTimeTrackingHack_by_SphinxITConsultingGmbH.rar), do what is written after "configured" in the following lines and restart jira. We defined a user group "hide-worklog-hack" which you must create in your jira. All users of that group do not receive any time tracking informations afterwards. we also use the jira greenhopper plugin. if you do not use greenhopper, you do not have to apply those changes; everything else still works the same. in the modified jsps and vms, our changes are marked with "sxhelpdesk" and "sxhelpdesk_greenhopper". note that you do not need to look at the modifed files - simply replacing the original is all you have to do.

introducing Notes

  • some time tracking information sources can still be accessed by directly entering urls. only the gui should be complete.
  • "configured" means here that you must use jira for this without any code modifications.
  • we implemented our modifications for jira version 3.12.1 and 3.12.3, which are slightly different.

modified files for restricted time tracking access:

  • atlassian-jira\includes\navigator\table\header.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\includes\panels\issue\actions.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\includes\panels\issue\view_timetracking.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\includes\panels\issue\create_timetracking.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\includes\panels\issue\view_subtaskissues.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\secure\views\issue\viewissue.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\secure\views\browser\browseproject.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\secure\views\user\viewuserissuecolumns.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\templates\jira\issue\field\timetracking-view.vm
  • atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\templates\jira\issue\field\timetracking-edit.vm
  • atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\templates\plugins\issueviews\single-word.vm
  • atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\templates\plugins\issueviews\single-xml.vm

greenhopper:

  • atlassian-jira\includes\panels\browser\tabpanels.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\secure\views\dashboard.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\templates\plugins\webfragments\system-navigation-bar.vm
  • atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\templates\plugins\webfragments\system-browse-project-operations.vm
  • jira-greenhopper-plugin-2.4.1-jira310-complete.jar\templates\greenhopper\jira\boards\operation\board-operation.vm
  • Email notifications
    • configured: users of hide-worklog-hack must not receive notification mails of any kind (notification schemes).
  • Issue Navigator
    • users of hide-worklog-hack only have output formats that do not present time tracking information.
    • users of hide-worklog-hack can not add any new columns. they can only delete, move, or restore the default settings.
  • View Issue
    • configured: all time tracking permissions must be disabled for hide-worklog-users (permission schemes).
    • users of hide-worklog-hack do not see any time tracking information and they only see comments, no 'all', no 'history', no 'worklog'.
    • users of hide-worklog-hack do not see any subissue time tracking information.
  • Create / Edit Issue
    • hide-worklog-hack users can no longer set the original or remaining estimate.
  • Work Log Reports
    • hide-worklog-hack users do not see any report links on the browse project site. note: the reports are still accessible by directly entering the correct url. to solve this issue you would have to modify each possible report.
  • greenhopper
    • hide-worklog-hack users can not use the links to the greenhopper planning board and task board while viewing an issue.
    • hide-worklog-hack users can not use the links to the greenhopper planning board, task boad, version board or chart board while viewing a project.
    • hide-worklog-hack users do not see the top level menu links to the planning board, task board, version board or chart board. note that they are still accessible by directly entering the correct url.
    • browse project: hide-worklog-hack users do not see the greenhopper tab, they can't access it any longer.
    • on the dashboard, the greenhopper link per project is still there but if hide-worklog-hack users click it they do not see the greenhopper report but just the project itself.
    • on the dashboard, hide-worklog-hack users can still add greenhopper portlets, but they have no possibility to actually see them anywhere.

Hopefully our solution is useful for some of you! Improvments are welcome.

Greetings,
Patrick Cemper

I did the patch for jira 3.13.1 and 3.13.2
but only for jira:
modified files for restricted time tracking access:

  • atlassian-jira\includes\navigator\table\header.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\includes\panels\issue\actions.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\includes\panels\issue\view_timetracking.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\includes\panels\issue\create_timetracking.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\includes\panels\issue\view_subtaskissues.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\secure\views\issue\viewissue.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\secure\views\browser\browseproject.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\secure\views\user\viewuserissuecolumns.jsp
  • atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\templates\jira\issue\field\timetracking-view.vm
  • atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\templates\jira\issue\field\timetracking-edit.vm
  • atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\templates\plugins\issueviews\single-word.vm
  • atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\templates\plugins\issueviews\single-xml.vm

So see the comment from Patrick Cemper: http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-2364?focusedCommentId=117120&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#action_117120

It is based on the patch of Patrick Cemper http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/25880/HideTimeTrackingHack_by_SphinxITConsultingGmbH.rar

You will find the patch-points with the marker 'sxhelpdesk'.

I put the files in directories that you just need to copy them at all.

The only difference from the 3.13.1 patch to the 3.13.2 patch is the only changed file atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\templates\plugins\issueviews\single-xml.vm.

Installation:

  1. make a backup of your current 3.13 jira-installation
  2. make shure that you have no other patches in the files above (helpful is the output of 'Modified Files' in Jira / Administration/ System/System Info) and jira is version 3.13.1 or 3.13.2
  3. Unzip the patch.
  4. Copy the directory atlassian-jira from files-for-patch-Jira-3.13.1 or files-for-patch-Jira-3.13.2 (depending on your target version) over your jira-installation replacing the original files.

Usage:

  • restart jira after installation
  • define a user group "hide-worklog-hack"
  • join the users to the group "hide-worklog-hack" who must not see time tracking information

I patched atlassian-jira-3.13.4.

In order to use this patch you have to create the group `view-worklog` and put there users who authorized to view the worklog. Anybody else won't see the worklog.

How to patch:
1) Download attached atlassian-jira-3.13.4.war-patch.zip
2) Scan it with your anti-virus !!!
3) Back up your existing jira
4) Unzip the file into your attlassian directory, zip contain the directory structures so patch files must end-up side by side with original files.
5) Run patch-all.bat that will use included patch.exe (from http://sourceforge.net/projects/gnuwin32/files/)
6) Restart server (required)
7) Patch will make a back-up of modified files, so you should remove them after you have verified that patch is working for you.

P.S. Patch is easily can be modified for newer versions of JIRA. Anyway you can reach me at ivanlatysh at gmail dot com.

Hi All,

This functionnality can be reached by another way : Global Actions.

OSworkflow (Component used by JIRA to manage Workflows) provides not only :

  • Initial-Actions (Create Issue),
  • Step Actions (Transitions from a Step to another) or
  • Common Actions (Same as Step Actions but share by different Steps).

The Global Actions are actions available from any Step, but defined only one time.
Another feature supported by OSWorkflow is the ability to defined as Result (Target Step) the same Step : Not by naming explicitely the target Step, but just by defining the Result Step as unchanged.

To reach the functionnality required in this issue, you will have to :

  • Remove the Time Tracking field from the View Screen,
  • Create a new screen where the Time Tracking field will be added.
  • Create a Global Transition in your Workflow
  • Append Conditions allowing the access to this Transition (Group Membership, ...)
  • Associate the created screen to the Global Transition

Also :

  • The Time Tracking will not be visible in the defaut View Screen,
  • A Global Transition will be available for any issue status and for authorised people only,
  • The Transition Screen will provide to these people the Time Tracking Field (for edition also)
  • The Global Transition will have no effect on the Issue Status

A such implementation may cover many security requirements issues :

  • Only some use are able to specify the Fix Version or Due Date,
  • More generaly, have some field editable depending on status.

To implement such Global Actions, Minyaa provides some improvement of Workflow Step edition, and Issue Edit operation. See Documenation

Try it now

Regards
Vincent

I came along this thread while searching how to restrict a group of users access to pretty much everything except viewing issues. I combined this functionality (group 'guests') together with the one from the original patches posted here (group 'workloggers'), for 4.2.1. The reason it's combined is that some of the files need changes for both groups. If you want the patch only for workloggers, delete all files containing references to 'guests' only, and delete conditions containing 'guests' in the other files.

So, the group named 'workloggers' has the original functionality and also:

  • patches pdfview plugin
  • removes work ratio search fields from issue navigator

The second group name is 'guests'. Users in this group cannot:

  • edit/manage dashboards (they only get the System Dashboard, no Tools menu, no Manage Dashboard links etc)*
  • save/share/manage/change favourite filters (links removed)
  • view project reports (removed reports link)
  • vote or watch (links removed)
  • edit their profile (they can view it, but cannot see email and edit links are removed)
  • perform any actions on an issue (removed all buttons in issue view)
  • perform any actions on issues in issue navigator (removed action column)
  • this was done by adding conditions to system-top-navigation-plugin.xml. I could not find a way to add an IsInGroupCondition or something like that and instead added a HasProjectPermissionCondition for permission COMMENT_ISSUE. (if anybody knows how to do this without modifying source, please let me know!) This is ok for me, since nobody in the guests group has this permission, but having a guest user able to comment would screw this up.

Note there are still a number of ways users not in the 'workloggers' group can view worklogs: by using gadgets project reports for instance. So basically for me this is pretty useless.. Yes the estimates and percentages are gone from issue lists, but a customer can still get a full timesheet report of your work.

However, by putting a user in the guests group this problem disappears.. Currently I only have one guest user, which is in the jira-users and guests groups only (hence not in the workloggers group) and has only browse permissions: this is ideal and yields almost a true read-only account.
In the future I'm probably going to add an extra group: I'd also want to be able to have users that can create issues, but not manage dashboards etc (the first three items in the guests list, hereby also preventing them from seeing reports having worklog info) or see worklogs.

Note that all these changes are accomplished by hiding the coresponding info/links. Clever users can get around this by entering the correct urls manually. I'm also not sure what happens if a user subscribes to an RSS feed for the Activity Stream.. (probably timetracking is in there as well?).

Patch installation: simply copy all files..
Use at your own risk, and please let me know if there is something wrong.

Hello to all friends of JIRA watching this issue and it's cousin JRA-1330.

Firstly on behalf of the JIRA team please accept our apologies for allowing this issue to be open for so long without any strong direction.

A few years back we took a long hard look at implementing field level security and came to the conclusion that it is not something we would be pursuing. We left this separate issue of Hiding Time Tracking open as it was the most popular field that customers wanted to hide. Whilst hiding any field in JIRA can be done, the implications of this are felt everywhere in JIRA: for example, we would need to adjust permissions, creating issues, editing issues, searching, xml, REST, notifications, reports, subtasks, GreenHopper and any plugin that may display that field - just to name a few. All this would be a very high development effort, and would come with the cost of not implementing other new features. Our focus for the general direction of JIRA is simplicity, and with another long hard look the complexity involved with hiding this field within JIRA has not changed. Therefore to be open and honest with all our customers we have decided to Close Won't Fix this issue.

Some of you may already know this but you can already hide time tracking and also any custom field via the commercial Field Security Plugin written by Quisapps. If hiding specific fields is critical for your environment, this plugin was developed for that specific purpose.

The decision to not implement time tracking field security was not an easy one for us, but we hope you appreciate our open approach to these requests. There are many exciting new features coming up in JIRA that we believe will have an even greater benefit to JIRA customers.

If you have any questions or concerns feel free to contact me directly.

Cheers,
Roy Krishna
JIRA Product Management
roy at atlassian dot com

while I can't describe how much I love Jira, there are some points at which Atlassian is doing it wrong. And here are two of them:

  • support for this should have been there from the very first release (there is so much one can hide, but not this? as I'm a programmer myself I assume it was implemented in a crippled way to start with and is now too hard to fix without refactoring nearly everything (the estimate for this issue was like 80days.   • ignoring an issue that was created rather early in Jira's lifetime, and has been actively commented on for 8 years is not exactly the way to please customers

I realize the issue may be time consuming to fix but it seems like there has been very little acknowledgement (none) from Atlassian that its a viable use case and is holding their product back from being a much more robust business tool. We'd really like to start by removing time* (worklogs being the most important) for a certain role. Once that can be accomplished there could be more specific access rules such as:
1. read only - allowing for the review of estimates but not allowing clients to enter time estimates for tasks
2. approval of estimates and actuals at the task level (probably best handled by a plugin like Tempo)
3. Review total actual time spent but not individual worklogs

It is a shame Atlassian has decided to not support this legitimate request from a large number of customers.

This permission should apply for both Jira and Greenhopper. So for example, in Greenhopper restricted users would not be able to see Hours Burndown Charts.

Hello All,

Now allow me to repeat myself when I first closed this issue - it was not something we took lightly. We spent a lot of our time internally discussing how to do it and it's feasibility. I understand that this disappoints many of our users, but opening new issues and commenting for us to reopen is not going to change our minds.

There may come a time in the future when the situation changes and we take another look at hiding time tracking estimates from certain users or we develop an alternative solution that does much the same thing. My two cents:

In our organization we have over 2,600 Jira users, including several hundred customers. We typically use a very simple issue type and workflow for customer-facing issues and create a separate internal issue to track the resolution. These internal issues have a much more complicated workflow and involve many more fields, including time tracking. At certain points, we go back and update the status of the customer-facing issue to let them know it's in progress or to convey other critical information, but we don't allow customers to see our internal issues. The customer-facing issues are sometimes segregated into a separate customer-facing jira project and sometimes we just use security levels within a single project to achieve this.

Yes, it can be a bit cumbersome at times. But it does the job of hiding our internal laundry without resorting to third-party plugins or modifications to out-of-the-box functionality. In the absence of field-level security, we've found this to be a workable solution.

I see some advantages in creating duplicate issues (customer and internal) - I mean it can solve two problems which we encounter today:
1. Sometimes developers forget to check 'Restrict to...' button on comment. It is easy to forget while adding lots of comments in different projects (some of them are internal some external). The result of such a mistake is serious: even if creator edit comment to the right restriction after creating, the e-mail notification IS SENT to all watching people already (in the moment of creation).
2. Even if all coments are created correctly - it is REALLY hard to read list of comments which are messed up - some of them are visible to customer, some of them not, and all are on ane list. I read such a long conversations consists of comments of different view restrictions - it is really not comfortable.

Another advantage could be that to one customer-issue we can link several internal-issues. Noramnd - do you use that possibility today ?

Lets think about it.

Here is how simple we solved this request with our JJUPIN plugin.

Here is how simple we solved this request with our JJUPIN plugin.

Are you sure you also cover API access and Word / XML exports from Issue Navigator?

@Holger
Changing the JIRA API is not in our scope, excluding fields from export or from REST is for sure.

What one can do more with help of Live Fields and JS is to disable the export functions depending on the users "profile" (decisions on group or role membership or other criteria).

HTH

@Florin Haszler (Kepler-Rominfo)

Hm, I don't understand. How should Live Fields prevent users from calling the REST API e.g. https://jira.atlassian.com/rest/api/2/issue/JRA-1 and retrieve full details of an issue incl. original estimates and worklog? Live Fields from JJUPIN just works on Issue View and Issue Navigator, but not on REST API, right?

@Holger Schimanski
The REST API can be disabled by configuration. If you need to have it on, then you can only filter the requests by external configuration for certain IPs (proxy).

Live Fields addresses client interaction in the browser outside the JIRA workflow/editing available actions.
The rest of JJUPIN is (a server side programming tool) within the workflow actions and Blitz Actions are performed within edition actions. Thus the three parts cover different areas.
For details asnd examples on live fields see here.

For more details, please contact me directly so we do not bother the others watching this issue.
HTH

How can this be marked as "Resolved" when there is no native way to do this yet in JIRA?

The Status in the workflow is not expressive, because Resolved does not mean, there is a solution for this. The Status with the Resolution contains the correct status information. This issue is not Resolved, but Rejected. But even the Resolution "Won't Fix" is not really correct, because Atlassian is obviously thinking of faster ways to solve it.

It would help, it the fields "estimate time", "remaining time", "time spent", could be handled separately, regarding the visibility. But this seems not possibly at the moment.

Atlassian has really improved JIRA a lot in the last two years, but sometimes it seems to be a hopeless case with them. This reminds me a bit of the "user name change" issue (https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-1549), where Atlassian needed exactly10 years to finally accept that it has to be possible to change user names ... However, customers succeeded after 10 years, so there is still hope for this issue ...

Obviously, displaying time tracking information to all users who can view a project makes it impossible that one can use time tracking and give external users (like customers) access to JIRA at the same time. There is no discussion required about such a topic, time tracking information is very confidential, and that's it. But Atlassian ignores this, and I guess because they simply don't get the point - and for sure are not using time tracking at all!. A simple workaround that e.g. ties the view permission for work logs and estimates to the permission of logging work would solve 80% of all problems, and you do not even have to introduce a new permission. However, instead of just programming this workaround (is for sure possible and should be a couple of hours of work), they are making a big deal out of it ("separate view port" and things like that), as if a workaround wouldn't be fully okay in this specific case. And to be honest, we are not talking about a feature request, we are talking about fixing a serious deficiency of JIRA.

So what can we do at the moment to solve our problems, as long as Atlassian decides to go on ignoring this issue? Not much, as the issue can only be solved in the JIRA core, it is impossible to write a "normal" JIRA plugin that addresses the topic in a proper way. But there are three plugins that try to offer a solution on different levels:

1. https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.quisapps.jira.jfs (the only working approach to apply security on field level, including time tracking fields, but requires a core patch for JIRA so that most users won't consider this being a real option)
2. https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.gebsun.plugins.jira.hidetimetracking (free plugin based on the technology of https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.keplerrominfo.jira.plugins.jjupin, works with JavaScript and displays all time tracking data once you deactivate JavaScript, can't be configured and only hides the data at few places).
3. https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/de.iconcept.ictime.jira-ictime (a complete time tracking solution that includes a workaround to hide time tracking data, works with JavaScript and displays all time tracking data once you deactivate JavaScript, tries to hide data at all places where time tracking information is displayed)

Adding link to Field level security permissions, but unfortunately also Resolved as Won't Fix, regardless the 440 votes.

This is a very important issue, because time tracking mustn’t be visible for everyone, especially "time spent", which allows checking, how long a person has been working on an issue.

Being a new JIRA user (still in testing phase), I find it unbelievable that Atlassian isn't able to resolve this issue, which exists for over ten years and which I ran into after only 4 days of using the product.

As a development company we are working very tightly with our customers. It is absolutly necessary for us to give them access to our bug tracking system, they must be able to report bugs, see their status, add attachments and comments and so on. On the other hand it is out of question to give them (at least not all of them) access to our internal time tracking information. This information is essential to us internally (for planning and controlling purposes) but we must be able to control, how and what of this information we communicate to our clients.

The fact tha a seemingly small issue like this (how difficult can it be to deny access to three fields for certain roles?) is such a problem to implement, raises serious doubts about the internal architecture of the whole system and of Atlassians understanding of the needs of their customers (or, worse, their commitment or capabilities to satisfy these needs!), This issue will certainly make us reconsider the decisiion of using JIRA (which is a shame, because apart from this issue the system seems to fit our requirements very well!)

The problem is, that Atlassian needs to implement field level security as a new concept to JIRA, which they decided not to do.

But how about having one JIRA project for customer interaction / voice of the customer (including documentation of quotes and invoicing if you like) and one to plan and steer your internal development activities (with tracking of internal estimates and real efforts), which is typically on more detail level that customer interactions (but you can link the issues).

This is a typical setup which also brings you other advantages as well. I wouldn't call this a workaround. It better matches your actual needs, because it is not mixing these two types of issue tracking.

Hope this helps.

Cheers,
Holger

Sorry, but it is not true that Atlassian would need to implement field level security as a concept to solve this problem - this is just the pretext they are communicating in order to get rid of the issue. The only thing required is a workaround in the code for this specific case. Yes, I understand that Atlassian does not want to code workarounds, but in this case, it would be justified without any doubt taking into account how absurd it is that a project management system reveals internal, private data to external customers. And Atlassian does not want to do address this issue, because they don't get the point - obviously they are not even using their own system to track time (oh, they probably wouldn't want you and me seeing their estimates and time spent ...). Your workaround is a workaround, because as stated by Martin, the typical use case is that customers access exactly the same issue like internal users do. Without any doubt, there might be use cases where your suggestion makes sense and brings additional benefits. But at least we are not using a project management system to duplicate projects and issues just because the system is not able to hide time tracking data from our customers. This is really a shame. And in addition it is stupid, because many customers (like we) would need to buy licenses with more users included if it were possible to give our customers access to JIRA ...

@Holger: no, it doesn't "match our actual needs better". Many of our clients are in software development themselves. We talk about issues on the exact same level of detail on both sides. They report and talk about a bug (or a requirement/task) in our part of the software in exactly the way do/we need it. They also need/want to watch status changes, set priorities and so on. They're often actively involved in sprint planning and/or backlog management. Same is true for issue assignment (clients need to know who to contact about a specific issue). We would need to duplicate every single issue/sprint etc, and also repeat every status update etc on both sides, which is (of course) unacceptable.

On the other hand, we use time tracking information not only for actually billing our customers, but also for validating/improving our (internal) estimations and also for identifying problems in our internal development process. We do not want to communicate any of this information "unfiltered" and without control to our clients: if we have clients with which we agreed about some sort of fixed costs, we cannot always let them know about that half of the issues, where our estimate (and thus the agreed amount) was too high (and for which we need to charge them more to finance that other half of the issues we underestimated).

If we have general problems with our estimations and/our development process, we want to analyse and address these problems first internally before we decide to communicate them.
Therefore we consider time tracking information as being "special" and more sensitive than other data in the issuer tracker.

Also we don't even want our customers always to know our internal estimations at all which may differ from the "official" ones for many reasons (training new developers being on of them for instance).

And as tobias_r pointed out, the "field level security" argument is a rather weak excuse: the time tracking information in question constist of a small and very well defined set of values/fields (time estimated, total time spent, time remaining). Adding a permission "View timetracking information" and a couple of if statements can't be that difficult (unless there are some really serious problems with the code). And considering the sensitive nature of these fields, some extra code resp. "hardcoded logic" seems quite justified.

Of course the same arguments could be applied to other fields (assigned user, issue status), and I can understand that Atlassian might fear to have the same discussion about these fields too. And of course this would eventually lead to field level security (which I totally understand would be a major change they aren't willing to do). But for me, the time tracking issue is a real "blocker" and I think, I'm not the only one...
@Martin: No you are not alone. We have a similar situation not being able to use time tracking in JIRA today. I agree with your comment 100%.
One more. It's a pain!
