I am currently piloting Jira as an issue/enhancement tracking tool to replace our existing system. To give project admin rights on 100+ active projects to the lead engineers just to allow them to manage versions is not the right way to go as they could break the rest of the setup.

We have an ongoing need to give full screen and field customization capabilities to an administrator for only a subset of projects. JIRA seems to support only a grant across all projects or a grant across none for these customization privileges.

For maintenance I want to minimize the number of different configurations, but for convenience I want to maximum the possible number of configurations. So there's a balance to be struck there.

For example, if the configuration is changed for one project, then I have ten other projects that I want to use the same configuration for, I could have some kind of "synchronize configuration" button. But the next configuration change to the one project may not apply to all the other projects. And the one after that may.

I've seen JIRA instances where the configuration of everything per project has lead to an unmaintainable system so I'm cautious about it. Perhaps the problem needs a better model of JIRA projects and how they are administered - inheritance perhaps?
Please implement. Adding my vote

By allowing project administrators to create their own forms, workflows, etc we could enabled full project management federation, thus going in the direction of modern IT methodology of empowered and self-organising teams. This change would also avoid big enterprises with thousands of projects from having to fire separate instances for each project

My organization would at least like the option of granting some of the existing project admin permissions to some users (Manage Versions and Components) but not other permissions (Project Role Membership). We have found over time the less knowledgeable project admins have been approaching the project security assignments like they are trying to kill an ant with a sledgehammer. This in turn creates a mess when they attempt to utilize common user group sharing.

I am currently evaluating JIRA 5.1 for use within my organisation. I was astonished to find that I could not allocate a "Create Project" permission to some users. It's simply not acceptable in our enterprise to bundle that permission in with blanket System Administrator permissions.

I would be very happy with the following solution:

  • A separate "Create Project" permission is added to the software.
  • A project can be tagged as a "Meta Project".
  • The System Administrator sets up one or more Projects, and tags it as a Meta Project.
  • A person with the "Create Project" permission, but without "System Administrator" permission, can only select from these Meta Projects, and can only enter a new Name, Description and Prefix. The schemes would be copied from that project. Once the project is created, the person would be a Project Administrator on that project.

Is there an update as to where this might be on the roadmap since the description indicates it could not be worked on for two years, but that was back in 2004. Given high number of votes and continued interested over the past 8 years, it seems something that should be a serious consideration at this point.
Update?

Adding my vote here.

Our take on this is to allow user with project administration permission to change everything in the project (e.g. select a new issue type scheme to use in a project), but not allow these users to create new schemes (that could be benificial too, but I don't need it).

Members of group administrators, would have access to modifying/adding new workflows etc.

Other than that, My Kro's take on the create new project scenario is also correct.

My contract-oriented client tends to create a separate JIRA project for each contract and generally does not share JIRA workflows, screens, etc. among projects. In our environment a JIRA Project Administrator should be able to create/edit/delete ANY JIRA configuration that affects his/her project. If this capability is available management discipline can be employed to handle conflicts between projects/administrators.

Nice-to-have options might include some or all of the folowing:

Prevent modification of configurations shared between two projects, unless the user has admin privileges for both.
Force creation of a new workflow, screen, etc. when a shared configuration is modified.
Alert affected administrators when a shared configuration has been modified.

Given that the issue has been going on since 2004 I am not really sure what my input could add but in my opinion this is a huge problem. I currently have a user who is close to a high level exec saying that I am being difficult because I want to know what changes they plan to make to the system as it can affect all of our Jira users as well as our other projects.

This user is an admin for his/her project and is asking to be able to change workflows and bug types for his/her project (which seems like a very legitimate/valid request) but if I give this user administrator permission they can change system security, workflows and god knows what else system wide. Also, unless I sit here and watch them there is no way for me to easily tell what they are changing. So I either need to ask the user to describe the changes and I make them for the user or watch the user and make sure that they are only changing information on their workflows / not touching security etc. Both of which make me sound like some sort of gestapo telling them what to do....

It's been suggested above that...

Splitting "Administer Project" into three permissions "Edit Project Role Memberships", "Edit Project Components" and "Edit Project Version" would help us a lot.

I do think that this could help - although thought would need to go into presentational aspects of permissions management. It's already hard to keep on top of things. Not hard to see what permissions an individual has... but hard to see what users have a given role globally (caveat... I say that as a JIRA v4.4.x admin).

Splitting "Administer Project" into multiple separate permissions would not deal with one problem that I have.. that anyone who has been given this permission is able to grant the same permission to anyone else. Thus, I add the Project Lead (and JIRA-administrators group) to the Administrators role in a project... and the next thing I know the Project Lead has gone and added 10 developers to the Administrators role. This is not good. I would even go so far as to call it a defect. But if it got looked at as part of this issue then no matter.

It's really good to see the Atlassian update. As requested, the following are the ordered priorities from our enterprise's perspective:

1. A separate "Edit Components & Versions" permission. Senior Developers frequently modify these in daily activities, but should not have access to the rest of the Project configuration. Also they should not be able to (easily) delete a Component or Version that is in use by issues. Thus this should be a permission that is quite safe to grant.

2. A separate "Create Project" permission. As an enterprise we want a fixed set of workflows & schemes so that we can document them and train our users accordingly. A Project Administrator role (eg. one per department) should be able to create and modify Projects, choosing from pre-defined schemes but must not be able to create or modify schemes or access System Administration areas.

3. "Project Schemes" (templates). Having to set so many schemes for a new project is arduous and error-prone. The ability for a Project Administrator to select a structure from a list of templates (or existing projects) would save a little bit of administrative overhead.

Yes, good to know that they finally get to this. Even if I think that not being able to to anything next 12 months is not ok.

Other than that, I agree with My Kro's priorities.

For us, the most important new feature is to allow the project admin to edit project-specific custom field options (i.e. the action "Configure Custom Field Context").
-David

I think I'd want the rights for project admins to change contexts locked out. What happens if PM for project A wants to add an item that the PM in project B (using the same context) doesn't want? That sort of thing has made me quite a few contracts - sorting out the messes made when people are given those rights and mess it up.

I'd prefer an approach where you can only change a context if you're the admin for ALL the projects using that context.

We use groups to give users access to a whole group of projects at once.

A project administrator should be able to add/remove users from groups.

We need the possibility for project admin to edit project groups (add/remove users from groups).
This is sure a task for project admin and not for jira-admin. On the otherside the jira-admin is not somebody who has the time to add/remove users/groups to projects.

Please integrade this featrue ASAP.!
Most important priority for us would be allow users to create new projects without being a JIRA Administrator as mentioned in JRA-1431

We resolve the Problem what a normal user was not able to create a project.
This is a python function which uses soap api and allows to create Jira-project and set certain user as Manager of this project

import suds,cgi
import os, sys

def createJiraProject(Name, Key, Desc, Leader):
    answer = "Project: " + Name + " successfully created"
    client = suds.client.Client('https://jira.sample.com/rpc/soap/jirasoapservice-v2?wsdl')
    try:
        # login to SOAP service
        session = client.service.login('loginname', 'password')
        # get necessary schemes
        ps = client.service.getPermissionSchemes(session)[1]
        ns = client.service.getNotificationSchemes(session)[0]
        iss = client.service.getSecuritySchemes(session)[0]



        # now actually create the project
        client.service.createProject(session, Key, Name, Desc,
                                            'https://jira.sample.com/browse/'+Key,
                                            Leader, ps, ns, iss)
        # set up correct roles for project
        pr = client.service.getProjectByKey(session, Key)
        # get objects of Project Roles
        pl_manager = client.service.getProjectRoles(session)[1]
        pl_developer = client.service.getProjectRoles(session)[0]
        pl_user = client.service.getProjectRoles(session)[3]
        # add user as project leader
        #print pl_developer
        client.service.addActorsToProjectRole(session, [ Leader ], pl_manager,pr,
                                              'atlassian-user-role-actor')
        # delete jira-groups from project roles
        client.service.removeActorsFromProjectRole(session, ['jira-administrators'],
                                                   pl_manager, pr, 'atlassian-group-role-actor')
        client.service.removeActorsFromProjectRole(session, ['jira-developers'],
                                                   pl_developer, pr, 'atlassian-group-role-actor')
        client.service.removeActorsFromProjectRole(session, ['jira-users'],
                                                   pl_user, pr, 'atlassian-group-role-actor')

    except Exception as e:
        # this is a java exception that consist of three parts seperated by ':'
        # "Server raised fault: com.atlassian....Exception: real error message"
        # we're only interested in the real error message
        answer = str(e).split(':')[-1]

    client.service.logout(session)
    return answer

Please take a look at this plugin: https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.wittified.jira.project-creator
Project Creator for JIRA allows the JIRA administrator to set up project templates and assign specific groups the permission to create new projects from these pre-defined templates. Project creation is super simple with it if I may say so myself
Nice plugin - is there something similar for groupadministration? We need the ability to create and admin groups but not users

Having tried both plugins TM Project Templates and Project Creator for JIRA:

TM Templates - I can see that by using actual projects as the templates you can conceivably populate them with more than just the schemes; they could be created with pre-defined versions, components and issues. The price (free) is also attractive. But unfortunately the way it is integrated into the menu is ugly and it's really hard to limit its availability to the groups I want.

Project Creator - perfect! I created a jira-managers group, configured the plugin to only accept this group, and bam, I have exactly what I wanted - project managers can create projects in 5 seconds and administer their versions, components and users but not tamper with their schemes. This solves the two biggest "Does Not Comply" requirements I had for my JIRA adoption project. Atlassian - you need to buy this plugin out! It is such a simple but crucial feature that has been missing from JIRA for eight years.

Would it be possible to let project admins make use of the permission helper of the admin helper plugin? So that project admins could easily determine why a user doesn't have access to somehting in their project.

The most frequent request from our 20000 users is to add custom fields to screens. We think a new custom field type which can wrap other custom field types could be a solution. Such a field could be added to trusted projects screen and the project administrators could add whatever field they need to the field on their own.

That's an interesting idea. I've thought about custom fields for a while and I think it requires having a field configuration scheme and issue type screen scheme per JIRA project. Once a JIRA admin had set them up, ideally by copying them from some template schemes, then allowing project administrators to change them is less of a problem. The other part to address is how to define different sets of options for select lists for each project.

Of course the down side to the above approach is that adding a new field to all JIRA projects would require making the change in each project individually. Perhaps with a more powerful REST API for administration that might be feasible.

Hi all.
I need the possibility of creation additional non-admin rights for creation/editing workflows (and schemes).
We have a lot of new projects and very ofter project leads know better what workflow they need to use and want to customize it theirselves. But I don't want to give them admin rights for this.

@Anton: I agree with you that it makes sense to delegate workflow administration but this should be controlled by its own permission. Think of script runner based workflow post functions that could be abused to do harm to the instance integrity and the operating system. It would also be great if one could control which plugin is available for workflow administrators and which is not.

I would like the permission to start a sprint to be separated out from project administration. We have large projects with multiple teams and don't want all sprint starters to have the ability to perform other administrative tasks, especially in light of possible expanded project administrative abilities.

Totally agree with Nancy, and Linking to a ticket I created (JRA-33573) to pull the role/membership management out of the 'administer project' permissions, which I feel has too wide a scope. (used by GH for sprints for example). It seems to me to distinguish between day-to-day activities (create sprints, update our URL) for initial/infrequent tasks (add users, change roles) from "reserved" functions (define new workflows, etc)

In addition to JIRA, how does this feature request apply to other Atlassian products (Crucible, FishEye, etc.)? The larger issue here is the lack of enterprise architecture support across all of the Atlassian tools, making it very difficult to deploy in larger environments. I'm excited to see the changes being addressed for JIRA (I've been following this discussion and waiting for this feature for a few years now), but we have the same issue with multiple tools that we otherwise find very useful.

Bartek, could you possibly comment on the extent to which other Atlassian tools will be affected?

Adam asked a good question! Fisheye/Crucible, for example, doesn't even have a concept of a project admin. We raised an issue for this, which is classified as a minor new feature - https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-2486.
-David

tl;dr - WORKFLOW EDITOR FOR PROJECT ADMINS PLS! (WITHOUT NEEDING jira-administrators MEMBERSHIP)

Atlassian,

Thanks for soliciting this feedback! I believe that project admins (who are not members of the jira-administrators group) being able to edit workflow is very important. The visual editor has made it much easier and intuitive for non-expert users to jump right into the workflow editor, so we could let project admins take more responsibility for crafting their workflow, but we cannot make these individual project admins members of jira-administrators group because they could mess up other areas of Jira and add themselves to user groups that would be equivalent to "SUDO" access. Please help us solve this problem.

Thanks!

  • Jon Verville, NASAGSFC

Hi Jon, I have to disagree with the idea of giving project administrators the ability to edit workflows. Right now, in order to start a sprint, a user needs to be a project administrator. We have users who have no business near a workflow who need the ability to start a sprint. If Atlassian creates a separate permission level for starting a sprint, then I would have less objection.

The most useful feature for is just linked and is not on the list. When already working on permissions please make sure that you create a global create project permission. ( https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-1431 )

Hi Jon Verville,

I believe that project admins (who are not members of the jira-administrators group) being able to edit workflow is very important.

I disagree with this because workflows are intended to be reused among projects. If given the ability to edit the workflow at project level, when one project admin makes a change it may affect several projects depending on workflow association with other projects.

Although visual editing is possible, there are numerous other factors to consider. Have you thought of post functions, scripts, validators, properties and any other complexities that can be attached to workflows by third party plug-ins?

I'm think your suggestion is going to cause extra burden to JIRA administration and management.

Regards,
Shaakunthala

JIRA already has facilities for detecting a particular user's privileges for a given facet of a project it seems logical to implement a condition so that only people who have access to modify a given workflow across all projects who implement it will have the ability. I administer JIRA servers and it would be great to be able to give my project managers and lead developers the ability to tweak the tool to their needs without giving them access to modify global settings. This limitation has caused my organization to place over 30 people in the jira-administrators group and this results in several breaking changes performed by staff who are unqualified. I realized this is a training issue but knowing that, pardon my language, I can let my devs run wild without pissing in someone else's sandbox would be great.
From my experience with JIRA in development life cycle, I think that giving the right to “Edit project versions” to none “jira-administrators” users is very important.
@Abdelkader Hamel - er, they already can. Versions can be maintained by project administrators, not system/jira admins.
@Nic Brough, Thank you for your clarification. I meant to say by “project administrator” not system administrator. All this issue is about delegating rights of project administrator.

@Abdelkader Hamel - ok, but I don't think you're right about what you think this request is about. The original question is about delegating a range of system administrative rights, not any of the three project admin rights. It's clear that the three project admin rights could be considered as a sub-set, but those rights are already more flexible than what this issue is really about. Additionally, version rights is a lot more complex than all the schemes, components and users, because it has a massive impact on the Agile stuff.

@Nic Brough, Actually my interests are more related to this issue JRA-24409.
Thanks again for your clarifications.

"JIRA Project Administrator" can be defined after creating one project, My organization needs one role (Not JIRA Administrators) using which people should be able to create projects and then can update/manage them. We do not want to have this dependency defined where Project administrators ask JIRA Administrators to create project for them.

Granting workflow editing privilege to Project Lead/Admins is a big deal to us. We have a very large user base with a mix of management styles. We don't have full-time jira admins. Placing this control in the hands of project leads/admins (usually ops management with good minds for workflow design) will save us a ton of time. This one has my vote.

Derek - there's an option here for those of us who want to allow project admins to edit workflow while we wait for improved granularity of admins. The Greenhopper plugin allows a system admin to swap a project to "simplified workflow". Project admins can then set up whatever workflow they want, at least in terms of the status in use (with some limits - the conditions, validators and post-functions are pared back to very basic levels)

When working with my customers, we always suggest creating a middle-of-the-road admin, by granting them the JIRA ADMINISTRATORS global permission. This way, they have Jira Sys Admins who take care of upgrades, backups, mail servers, etc. Then we have what we typically call the JIRA Power User (with the JIRA Admin role) who maintains custom fields, workflows, screens, etc., then we have the Project Admin who simply manages their components, versions and project team members. This seems to be a good balance. I personally, would not want all Project Admins in the system configuring custom fields, workflows, etc. I think these 3 roles in the existing system are fine and cover all the bases.

@Shari : I think you misunderstood. The issue is that Project Admins need to have some access to functionality that is now reserved for what you call "Power Users" (design some screens, ..). The only way to do this now is to add them to the "Power Uzser" group, ending up with much to much people that can add custom fields, ...) This is really unmanageable. F.e. we have > 100 projects, > 50 Project managers, but we would limit adding custom fields to 2 or 3 people, in mean time allowing Project Managers to decide what fields are available on what screens...
So there is no question of "all Project Asdmins adding custom fields, workflows, etc", but just be able to define much more in detail what a Project Admin can do. Currently it's a all-or-nothing setting

> which are the most important?

1. 'Component-like' field customization.
I.e. we could have a field type like 'project-customizable list'. Then if we have such fields in our schema, each project admin should create their own list for such fields, the same way as they do now for Component.
Why: fields like Customer, Business Line, Environment, Database, Requesting Department etc.

2. Ability to add project-specific fields to the common shared schema.
Why: we need a common 'core' configuration to have the same workflow (=process) and the same data model for reporting for all projects in the organization, but it's OK for individual projects to supplement this core with more specific fields that could help them be more productive.

We're on JIRA 4.4.3 and "users" can manage versions without being project administrators. So I fail to understand any benefit to the new approach of only have project administrators perform this function. Our developers see managing their project version and code go in hand in hand with their workflow.

Can someone tell my why this was changed? Because it certainly discourages us from upgrading.

Regards,
Ron

As a Jira global administrator, I would particularly like the capability of having the Jira (project) Administrator role be able to create new projects and assign the appropriate workflows and issue schemes to them. This would help shift that essentially administrative task into the administrative functions of my organization.

One of the use cases for project administration is as follows for us:
The use case is that there are certain lists associated with a project that are dynamic and project admins want to be able to manage these lists in order to ensure that data is captured correctly without having to wait for system admin to update the list. Our JIRA users have been asking this for quite some time now.

--Manju

At our site, we have several different Jira template projects that serve as archetypes when we set up new projects. Looking at the archetype gives you the correct schemes to select for a helpdesk project vs. a software development project vs. a customer implementation project, etc. I would be reluctant to give power users the ability to create their own jira projects, but if they were only able to select from these kind of pre-defined archetypes, that would be acceptable.

The most common customization requested from a project is for additional field values. Right now, this requires a system administrator to establish a new context for the custom fields in question and to copy all the existing values into that new context while they add the new values.... a lot of work for a relatively simple request.

The second most common customization request is for additional fields. Adding a new field for a single project has to be done by the system administrator, but it's relatively straightforward unless they want the field to be required. If the field is required, we must also modify either the field configuration or workflow(s) depending on when the field is required. I would be okay with allowing project admins the ability to create new project-specific custom fields, but I would be reluctant to allow them to modify field configuration schemes or workflows. It would be too easy for them to shoot themselves in the foot or to subvert standard business process requirements we've implemented in the workflows.

I would like to ask that the ability to start/complete a sprint be removed from project administrator privileges as part of this endeavor. It would be very nice to be able to give people the ability to administer workflows for projects without full admin privileges, but the people who administer workflows might not necessarily be the same people who administer a sprint. We have some very large projects that require a big group of team leads to have the ability to administer sprints. I would not want those people to have the ability to get near the workflow. Please resist using the project administrator permission as a catch all.

I can't believe that this wasn't included in the JIRA 6.0 release and is still not assigned. We too would like to be able to assign people the ability to create projects without giving them permission to edit users, or create application links or update plugins or .... any other JIRA system-wide admin tasks.
Any updates on this?

Hi everyone,

A quick update on this request. As I have informed you back in July, this is something we are targeting in the near future (that being 12-month time frame as seen from July). Currently one of JIRA dev teams is working on a related story: JIRA Configuration Audit Trail JRA-3157. Once the work is completed the same team is scheduled to switch over to work on this request. If all goes according to the plan (which unfortunately I cannot promise at this time) we will release Delegated Project Admin functionality in the release after the upcoming JIRA 6.2.

Cheers,
Bartek
JIRA Product Manager

How are you planning on doing anything with workflow editing, when that functionality allows triggering execution of scripts/functions/etc that run in an unrestricted context?

You'd have to implement some sort of restricted workflow editing that didn't allow configuring of any option that the user themselves didn't have access to use. Similar to what is done in the 'bulk change' UI now.

It seems pretty obvious that Versions management should be separate from overall project admin. In an agile environment lots of people (maybe everyone) can do a release. The idea of a team leader/project manager as gatekeeper for release management is very old fashioned.

We have a large organization with multiple projects. We need a profile available so we can grant users permissions to create and maintain users and user groups but who have don't have access to any other Admin function.
Came here to request exactly the same as Ted. Group Management should not need full JIRA Administrator privileges, and should be as delegatable as Project Role Management, for example.
We would like project admins to configure the issue security for their projects by themselves something like they can do for components and versions.

as per the email requesting our feedback on the fix approach, For most of this I don't even care anymore since I created my own interface that allows projects to do most of this themselves now anyway. My main concern now is that when you do implement this you allow us to enable/disable these new features as we want.. per project.

As an example we have a very strict corporate workflow as part of our quality program and giving projects the ability to change this would not be good. However there are a few projects that don't have to follow this process so it would be nice for them to have their own workflow and be able to manage that workflow without affecting others.

For field options we have many groups with their own contexts but many in the default context.. We don't want groups to be able to edit the default context but if they are in their own context they can. There are some fields we never want them to be able to alter as part of our quality process requirements.

We need the following types of admin roles:

  • System Administrator (addons install, addons config, global settings etc)
  • Access Administrator (users, groups, roles, user directories, permission schemes etc)
  • Issue Type Administrator (Create / Edit / Delete Projects, Schemes (notifications, permissions, workflow), Issue Security Levels for a project, Issue Types, Custom Fields, Screens, Workflows)
  • Per Project Roles including Administrator (Project Roles, Components, Versions, Project Details, Issue Collectors) - this can be done as per current project administrator role except each of the listed items need to be available as individual project permissions.

I'd like to see the permission level required for adding/defining web hooks separated as well. Several external addon services are requiring their integration to be set up with a full administrator user - and that is just excessive. In most cases, the only reason that is happening is because of the permission required to create the web hook.

What we need for project administrator is :

  • ability to manage custom field options and default value
  • ability to manage the notifications

What we need for project administrator is (in addition to what is now possible):

  • Ability to select schemes for their project.

The ability to edit custom field options is our top priority.
-David
Agile (GreenHopper) users, see also: GHS-5035. I think, this topic is related.

A permission to allow a specific external non-admin to create and/or edit software versions is critical.

Our developer may generate internal releases such that although the release schedule remains the same, the version number of the submitted client will change. Currently they are unable to commit a defect resolution to the correct version number without communicating first to the project admin, who must then enter the version number.

If a specific user is able to update the software version, it would be a real boon.
Having this is vital. We should be able to pick and chose fine grained permission. For example I should be able to delegate group management to one user but not necessarily all the other permissions.
The ability to allow project admins to edit Workflows is key to us.

The ability to prevent project admins from updating Workflows is key to us as we have workflows which are shared by 30+ teams and allowing 1 of the project admins to negatively impact 29 other teams would be bad. It is challenging enough to ensure our jira administrators are not making changes to shared workflows, screens, custom fields, etc. without first knowing all of the jira projects they could be impacting.

We have about 4500 users and several hundred projects in our jira instance. We've created custom workflows for some projects, but we prefer to keep the number of workflows relatively small because it's much more maintainable that way. If you need to drop or change to a different plugin that's providing a condition or validation, for example, you'd have to go modify all the workflows that are using it. Or maybe you discover the fact that there's no "transition issue" permission (see JRA-11564) and you decide to handle this by making sure that every transition checks to see if the person has the "assignable user" permission. Again, you'd have to modify every workflow and make sure that future modifications stay aligned.

The bottom line for us is that we definitely do NOT want a project admin to be able to modify workflows. If they have this ability, we'd end up with a lot more work on our hands to support them and to make sure they are doing things correctly and to handle impacts from global changes to plugins, etc.

The ability to prevent project admins from updating Workflows is key to us as we have workflows which are shared by 30+ teams and allowing 1 of the project admins to negatively impact 29 other teams would be bad. It is challenging enough to ensure our jira administrators are not making changes to shared workflows, screens, custom fields, etc. without first knowing all of the jira projects they could be impacting.

+1
We have this same requirement. 500 projects with some shared things between large groups of projects would be disastrous if Project Admins had the permission to make changes. Just to think of the few that make requests several times a year for workflow changes would put a lot of stress on the server if they had to power to transitioning tens of thousands of tickets themselves while they figure out what they really want. Because what user, besides a System Admin, uses DEV to test a workflow or other change...

I think the better way to describe that - cause I have cases in either direction:

A permission should exist that grants ability for a given project (or whole system) to choose a workflow, or other schemes in the system

A permission should exist that can be assigned to a given workflow specifying users that can edit that workflow.

Understanding that an issue that will come up is that workflows are inherently (as currently implemented) - privilege escalating. So you'd need to have some sort of mechanism to limit what the user could do in the workflow - i.e. say "This workflow is limited to user-invocable actions, no script execution.".

I think it needs to be fined grained so that you can designated IF a project admin can do so and for what workflows. Some of us need to have that ability and others dont. Thus it needs to be something we can toggle and assign as necessary.

I think that workflows is the biggest part of this issue because:

1. It is something that can differ for teams that are different than your development team (i.e. if you start with Jira for development and want to expand to support/marketing/project managment/etc.) THAT is (a) when you want a different workflow and (b) the time you want to give those group leaders a project with administrative rights without granting them jira admin rights

2. Workflows are the thing you don't want to mess with once they are set up and working, and thus should have permissions on them.

IMHO

long comment - hope it adds value

Some general principles going through my head on this one:

  1. Minimisation of config items is good for maintainability and performance
  2. With power comes great responsibility (thanks spiderman!) - you need to work with those who share your config before making changes
  3. Self service cannot be undervalued (even if this means your company accepting additional risks)

Based on some of these tensions, providing project admins the controls they really want (lets be honest - project admins would like to change everything), it's going to be a long / hard journey to make them happy by incrementally adding low-risk pieces.

Options:

  1. We could work on lowering the significance of principle #1 and #2
  2. Market the idea like crazy that being able to self-service on some of the lower-risk functions is better than nothing
  3. Think a bit differently

Atlassian has kicked many goals recently in making the Admin screens much more easier to:

  • Understand the current config for your project
  • Understand what shares your config
  • Make good design decisions on how to implement your required changes.

Why not expose the entire JIRA admin setup to project admins? Let them design their proposed changes and submit them to a global admin or community to review and approve.....much like how a pull request works in GIT. Once its approved the changes can be implemented.

This is an extension of the way some config changes already go through a draft mode before being applied to live projects.

Pros:

  • Project admins feel empowered to make changes
  • Project admins can propose changes in the most efficient way (no more verbose support tickets - just a list of schema / field changes people can review using the JIRA UI)
  • Maybe this is less dev effort to implement? Atlassian would need to comment
  • Central admins / community still have the opportunity to guide the community to make good decisions for the overall platform
  • Project admins / central admins can feel a better combined sense of ownership for JIRA. When central admins say things seem messy and out of control - project admins can see it too!
  • Letting project admins peruse the greater JIRA config may provide additional opportunities for them to learn from other projects and their configs.

Cons:

  • Some project admins may be overwhelmed with navigating the overall config screens.
  • Some project configs may be sensitive??? Not sure on this requirement
  • Not sure what to do with concurrent editing / submissions of config changes.
  • No doubt there's others i haven't thought of.

Have a think about this approach. In my eyes it could be a winner.

If something like this isn't possible or you'd like to do a combined approach , from what i've seen, priority should be on:

  • Create Projects
  • Maintaining groups
  • Update custom field choice lists
  • Adding existing custom fields to projects

Work on the granularity of (project) admin rights? Because projects of very different natures tend to cohabit in a single instance.
For example, Quality might grant the right to edit custom field options but not the right to edit workflows, in "Marketing project A" but not in "Dev project B".

I try and keep workflow, permission, notification, issue type, screen shemes scheme etc project specific. One per project otherwise someone can make a change that impacts someone elses project. We have a default copy for new projects scheme for each of these and the admin makes a copy renames it and reassociates it. What you dont want to do is offer them the option to add in someone elses scheme becase they could then potentially modify that scheme that is shared with another project. We also have three types of user groups specific to each project "Users" "Assignable Users" and "Project Admins". What we are lacking is:

1. The ability for project leads to add/manage new users and associate them to their project groups
2. The ability for project leads to add/remove/edit fields on their forms ( field configuration, screen schemes)

Again you have to be careful otherwise they can modify something that is shared with another project and unless one of your main tasks in jira admin you are just not going to know this. The flexibility of Jira whilst helpful can also cause issues unless you have implemented your own parameters and business processes because there are so many ways to effectively do the same thing.

I do not see the same level of need for project users to create custom workflows. I think if each new project was set up with a basic workflow, issue type scheme, screen scheme, notification and user group scheme that was specific to that group then you could open up the permissions a little.

Alternatively you extend out the permnission scheme for the project which has an admin section with settings such as:

Create new Jira users
Add existing Jira users to view your project
Rename project
Change values of an existing screen fields

etc - stuff that's not going to hurt other groups ...

Louise

Please provide fine grained permissions for every project administration functionality.
I would love to see permissions for Versions, Components etc.
Then let the users decide which permissions they want to associate to a role.

Since we're taking an incremental approach, we'd love to hear what your priorities for what order you'd ask for

For me "custom field by project" has highest priority. See also the comments of 20 more users in JIRA-5749.

Since we're taking an incremental approach, we'd love to hear what your priorities for what order you'd ask for - i.e. among the elements in JIRA that you'd like a project administration to be able to modify, which are the most important?

The ability to create new projects and edit project details is our priority. Our business is a constant stream of small projects, and everyone on the team needs to be able to create projects.

Since we're taking an incremental approach, we'd love to hear what your priorities for what order you'd ask for

The ability to add 'custom field by project' has definitely highest priority for me as well, just like Stephan had noted above.
With 12.000+ employees in a digital agency context, we have hundreds of projects, many of which require some customization on the field level (e.g. specific browser dropdown by project). Maintaining this centrally is an admin's nightmare and ultimately our project teams suffer, because we cannot allow customization for projects in JIRA, which should be a key strength of the Atlassian suite.
Our priority is to create projects and to select the different schemes (worflow, field configuration, issue type, permissions, etc.) associated with it.

We have a request for Administrator Projects permission.
We hope that one user can manage the project(configure roles, notifications..), but can't see and manage the development tools.
If the user's permission is removed from View Development Tools and given Administer Projects, he can't see the Developent panel in the issue but see Development Tool in Administration of the project.
A separate "Create projects" permission is the highest priority

A separate "Create projects" permission is the highest priority

As requested, feedback regarding priority:

Managing project versions needs to be separate from full administration rights for a project. This is often required by project managers who should not at the same time be able to change the technical functionality of the project (like workflows or fields). We see versions more in the domain of users than of technical administrators.

Managing workflows is very important in true agile environments. Each team tweaks their process during each retrospective. Right now we have to go through a lot of trouble dealing with admins to get it working right which takes weeks instead of minutes. If we want to try something new or different it is a big headache. It might not be important for waterfall teams, but since greenhopper/agile is geared toward agile methodologies, I hope your team will consider this as high a priority as we do.
Personally I'd be surprised if every team was tweaking their workflow every retrospective. If they are, it sounds like you're doing agile wrong.
Well ... that would be iterative.
If you want an agile workflow ... try To Do/Ready --> In Progress --> Done

...and then we want bamboo to show builds in hipchat - workflow change
...and then we want reviews requests to show in hipchat - workflow change
...and then we want a status change to send an email to QA before being marked as Done - workflow change
...

True agile environments are always evolving.

...but I appreciate all the helpful replies
could we consider making it possible to add users the ability to manage individual workflow/screen/issue/notification and permission schemas

Would really like to see the ability to manage custom fields per Project, by the Project Administrator. It is probably the most requested ability I get from people. Although, since there are performance implications with having LOTS of custom fields, it would be nice to apply a limit per project on how many custom fields they are allowed to have. This could be one limit set globally, but it'd be nice to be able to set it per project.

A little off-topic but referring to @david hergert i need to mention again that Atlassian has to find a way to cope with more fields per instance, let's say 10000.

At the moment this inhibits consolidation of many under-the-table JIRAs into one Datacenter JIRA

In my opinion, if I had 10k custom fields per project, then I probably did something wrong.

Fields shouldn't be duplicated for each project. That would be inefficient. Project admins should be able to create custom fields and scheme it into their projects. The system would make this field available in a list for all project admins to add it to their projects if they wish. A custom field is "tagged" as being "owned" by the creator's project and can be deleted by admins of that project only if they are not used by any other projects. Obvious global admins can override all of this.

With what little knowledge I have of the jira codebase, this seems to me to be the most optimal way of implementing "project-based" custom fields using the existing architecture.

Regarding the fields, comment from Dieter, we try to use the same fields in all projects, not showing them in all projects through the use of different field schemes.

And we use also additional contexts of some fields in some projects, in order to reduce the number of items in that fields in mark one as the default one. This is useful, especially if the same field should be used in different projects, but with different options.

The additional context means some more work for the Jira admin, but In my opinion, at least these administration effort could be shared with a Project Administrator, since the global settings would not be affected.

And we use also additional contexts of some fields in some projects, in order to reduce the number of items in that fields in mark one as the default one. This is useful, especially if the same field should be used in different projects, but with different options.

The additional context means some more work for the Jira admin, but In my opinion, at least these administration effort could be shared with a Project Administrator, since the global settings would not be affected.

This administrative work of editing custom field option values can be shared with project admins using Project Specific Select Field. This might be an option for you while waiting for implementation of JRA-3156.

Cheers,
Holger

We at Wittified have released another add-on that might help here (in addition to the Project Creator for JIRA): https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.wittified.jira.project-admin-notifications-editor

It allows the delegation of administrating of notification schemes to project owners by branching the notification schemes as necessary. There is some controls about the number of users in a group that can be added to a project (just in case somebody decides to add the entire user base).

We really need to be able to associate field contexts with project groups instead of projects.

Without that, I don't see how to make project creation easy. We couldn't find a project template plugin that can associate a new project with field contexts, so the only workaround is to create specific fields and field configurations for every project template. Yurk.

I want to emphasize Holger Schimanski comment. We don't want a lot of new custom fields, but the ability of a project lead to add individual values for his/her project.
What we don't want is that project leads can modify existing workflows. This would lead to a rather unmanaged state of workflows which is not acceptable for me.
Modify permissions? No, only choosing a security scheme would be OK for me.
Changing the notification scheme is also OK for project leads.
Running imports of issues from CSV-files into his own project would also be OK.

The general idea behind my comment: a project admin can not change central corners of the system, like permission schemes, workflows, issue types, fields.
But he can add/modify data to all the fields and projects he is assigned to.
Regards Martin

There needs to be great flexibility to who we can extend the additional permissions to.

I think flexibility is the most important aspect of these new permissions.

I cannot envision a "one-size-fits-all" solution for the set of projects in my own installation, much less for all Atlassian customers.

Sorry to be late to the party (it's really hard to parse 200+ comments), but I'll add on to the request for a specific Version management permissions. It really doesn't scale well to give complete project admin rights to create an object that really should be controlled by developers.

This reminds me of something. Judging by JIRA Agile (formerly GreenHopper) Atlassian seems to try and find/define the "one true way". @Aaron - JIRA Agile's permissions were on the front of my mind as well. GHS-5035 in particular, where sprint management is controlled by Project Admin. Broad usage of privileges in the past and present concern me.

@Darien - When I said "might please some users," I was referring to people within my company not other Atlassian customers
I know that everyone operates differently.

> This is very true. Projects should not be sharing workflows unless nessesary.

Holy smokes, I have to comment on this. I think the vast majority of Jira instances that have more than a couple users & a couple projects would define the opposite as a best practice - that is, projects should be sharing workflows unless necessary, i.e. until they have demonstrated a specific, real need to be different.

In the instance of Jira I administer with about 400 active projects, one workflow scheme covers 350 projects, and a second covers 40 projects. That leaves about 10 projects with custom workflows of various types. If we let every PM customize every single project's workflows, the administration overhead for an instance holding 400 active projects would be 10X as large as it is right now, which is half the time of one person.

A few advantages of sharing workflows that immediately come to mind are the low administration and user training/familiarization costs, like-schemed projects can pass issues between themselves easily, and the underlying status are identical enough that agile/kanban boards can pull in issues from multiple projects without having issue/status compatibility problems.

That said, I would really like the option to selectively allow non-administrators to edit a project's workflow. It certainly wouldn't be the norm, but there are principals and lead pm's that I would like to give the ability to edit their specific workflows while keeping administration rights on our Production instance clean.

-Kelly G. Schoenhofen

If we let every PM customize every single project's workflows, the administration overhead for an instance holding 400 active projects would be 10X as large as it is right now, which is half the time of one person.

Then you scale up the administration. You let each Project Group Administrator manage their own project. If they need interop between projects, then it's up for the two Project Group Administrators to decide and deconflict, accordingly.

Why is there this need for a single, monolithic root admin to control this, all the time? Why not adopt a distributed model to help scale the management functions of aspects that are clearly project-oriented settings?

...would define the opposite as a best practice - that is, projects should be sharing workflows unless necessary, i.e. until they have demonstrated a specific, real need to be different.

Would you believe that JIRA is used for more than just code development/tracking? Would you believe that JIRA is being used for any type of generic workflow management?

Shocking, I know. But I hate to break it to you – but when you start using JIRA outside of traditional code development/tracking, you need custom workflows to support that use case, on a per project basis.

So, if Atlassian wants to empower users to leverage JIRA for more than just code development/tracking, then allowing configurable workflows on a per-project level (to be controlled by a Project Group Administrator, at least) is sorely needed.

I'd go as far and say there's also a need for a per-component custom workflow capability (to be defined by Component Admins), but I'm thinking some folks may treat this as even further taboo.

Think outside the box. JIRA can be used for so much more. If only this feature were supported...

why don't we all just stop telling each other how to do our jobs. in 10 years when Atlassian assigns someone to this, they will implement something that tells us all how we have to do our jobs.

This was a simple feature request to allow project admins to edit their field configuration values so we don't have to give 200 people Jira admin rights to do something so basic and somehow got bastardized into a workflow debate to which there isn't even an assignee. Removing my vote and un-following as these replies are getting to be more like spam than anything useful.

I agree with Jeff. Thanks for the November 5th update, Dave. We appreciate getting updates and realistic estimates, it helps us plan better.
Actually I'd rather they just implement the things they say they're going to, especially when they're obviously very dearly wanted by many of their customers.

+1 for Mary's comment, way up ahead from July 3rd.

Workflows:
Yes, we need project admins to be able to create and manage those. Our teams work in silos and their workflows are very different from each other. It's like I have 40 companies all using the same jira instance but they all operate differently so very few elements can be shared.

Plus there is no easy "Workflow Browser" (what is there now is just a dump of the existing workflows, it's not something usable if you want to do say a one-button click to see the diagram for it), due to the nature of how our instance grew we have many workflows that no one knows about unless they take the time to click and research. You can view all the workflows from the Admin console, but when you're creating a new project/switching schemes, you have to select from a drop-down...so you can't even think, "so-and-so project uses that workflow, that'll work for us". No one has time to research all the workflows one by one to see if it'll work for them, so yet another one gets created, adding to the list. For the most part, our project managers don't all work with each other, they don't care about other teams' workflows/processes, they just want to maximize their projects and only their projects.

If you knew how many admins I have on my instance, you'd be shocked...but this is necessary because project managers were continuously needing to make changes, and they needed them asap to move forward (some of our projects are incredibly fast-paced).

Right now we have WAY too many cooks in the kitchen, as a result of how the admin permissions are "all or nothing". As a Jira admin, I couldn't care a less if a project admin wants to change his workflow. Nor do I want to sit down in a meeting room and half to log in, then walk through step-by-step all the changes they need to make because they can't do it themselves. You could set a permission field on the workflow itself if you want it to be editable by project admins or only jira admins.

Some random thoughts.

I am surprised this is not already built in. Managing project workflows versus managing system permissions and access rights should be very separate entitlements within the platform. How can workflows be considered 'jira administrator' function, many corporates now distinguish between service management and support versus project admin. I see this was raised 10 years ago, how many votes are needed to get it looked at ?
