  • Edit group member
  • Manage custom field options (not context)

We really need this functionality, specifically adding and changing options for custom fields.

Maybe Project Specific Select Field can solve your request. With this plugin project admins can add project specific options to custom fields (single and multi select).

@Holger Schimanski Thanks for the heads up. We're using the Cloud version, which does not allow for plugins (as I am sure you know). It's great that you were able to fill in the gaps, but I think this functionality should be present OOTB.

We at Wittified just released Delegated Administration for JIRA ( https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.wittified.jira.delegated-admin ).

With Delegated Administration for JIRA you can:

  • Delegate the selection of schemes to the project administrator(s) for:
  • Workflow schemes
  • Issue Type schemes
  • Issue Type Screen schemes
  • Field Configuration schemes
  • Permission schemes
  • Notification schemes

In addition to this you can allow the project administrator(s) to edit and maintain their permission and notification schemes locally on their project.

But as an admin you can still maintain control by limiting the schemes that can be used (and the groups that can be used in permissions and notification schemes ). At any point - rolling back to a known "good" scheme is easily done through the History feature.

That's absolutely awesome and unfortunate at the same time. Hopefully this does not mean Atlassian will choose to leave this feature out of the core product, but if they do add it, I am sure your plugin will provide some nice bonus features! I did see in the JIRA 4.0 EAP release notes, they are beginning to prep for this ability. JIRA 6.4 EAP 14 (m14)

Creating a new project now creates a project-specific issue type scheme, workflow scheme, screen scheme and issue type screen scheme for that project. This change applies to all project types, except for the 'JIRA Classic' project type, which still uses the shared default JIRA schemes when used to create a new project. This change is to enable more flexibility around editing JIRA schemes on a per project basis.

Folks at Wittified,

This is very good to hear. Have you performed load/stress testing on your plugin yet? How does it do on an enterprise scale?

Currently, I have 1100~ Projects on my JIRA Instance, with 200~ Workflow Schemes (the numbers grew because of the Agile Simple Workflow). As you can see, administration is becoming a tedious task for my team. I was just wondering what will happen if we have 1000 unique schemes (Field, Screen, Issue Type, Workflow) for each Project?

Hi Daniel/Wittifield.
This is indeed great news. I'd also be curious to hear about your performance testing results. We also run a very large instance with hundreds or projects, but are currently fairly restrictive on how much customization we offer because of the resulting overhead for our central support team.

It's a huge bottleneck only allowing admins the rights to create and work with release versions.

It subscribes to view of monolithic infrequent releases, with only a small subset of people in your organization that controls these, which is very far from todays thinking of continuos delivery/deployment.

In my organization we release frequently (~every day), and using jira versions is a great way of tracking all of this, the only issue is that having a single person or small group of people being required to create and work with versions doesn't scale. To get around this issue I've been forced to make everyone Admin's, which is far from ideal.

Would love to see version creation being a configurable permission. :+1:

Our main need is to have a new global permission, such as JIRA User Administrators, so a particular group would be able to create/edit users and groups, but nothing more.

We have experienced too many "bad idea" misconfigurations on our JIRA instance due to having too many cooks in the kitchen as JIRA Administrators, so having this limited global permission would be a major plus.

Programatically, we accomplished that by moving group management out of Jira and into Active Directory & Crowd. Either option (AD or Crowd) would let you delegate user management but not give them Jira Admin access.

Pragmatically, the people that do have Jira Admin access but aren't supposed to touch the configurations haven't been a problem; this was accomplished through education and professionalism. We're all adults here - if someone is told they can only do X with their rights and they just can't help themselves and make changes elsewhere, then they need to find a new place to work and probably a new career as well.

-Kelly

Apparently I am missing something in our configuration then as our JIRA instance is currently integrated with AD, but we still need to create the user in JIRA under JIRA Delegated Authentication Directory instead of JIRA Internal Directory.

If there is a way to create a user in AD and have them automagically added to JIRA and the jira-users group without the use of Crowd, please advise me where to find the doc to make this configuration change.

Thanks,

Terry

Take a look at https://confluence.atlassian.com/plugins/servlet/mobile#content/view/229838545

In particular:
Setting

Description

Copy User on Login

This option affects what will happen when a user attempts to log in. If this box is checked, the user will be created automatically in the internal directory that is using LDAP for authentication when the user first logs in and their details will be synchronised on each subsequent log in. If this box is not checked, the user's login will fail if the user wasn't already manually created in the directory.

If you check this box the following additional fields will appear on the screen, which are described in more detail below:

Default Group Memberships
Synchronise Group Memberships
User Schema Settings (described in a separate section below)

Completely agree with @TimMcCormick :

It's a huge bottleneck only allowing admins the rights to create and work with release versions.
It subscribes to view of monolithic infrequent releases, with only a small subset of people in your organization that controls these, which is very far from todays thinking of continuos delivery/deployment.
In my organization we release frequently (~every day), and using jira versions is a great way of tracking all of this, the only issue is that having a single person or small group of people being required to create and work with versions doesn't scale. To get around this issue I've been forced to make everyone Admin's, which is far from ideal.
Would love to see version creation being a configurable permission. :+1:
Tim's issue is also a problem for us - 'far from ideal' is right on.

I second that. This is clearly a blocker for using JIRA in agile projects. For my organization, the roundtrip to get a workflow change is three days. If they get it right the first time. End result is that no-one is bothering to ask them for updates and as such JIRA ends up being considered an inferior product.

So young.. So naive - friends - this issue is merely 11 years old - that means its just only about to get aged well enough for the jira dev team to look into whether they know what to do... we should expect that the reject the task, because its not part of the strategy or something, with the next 3-5 years from now...
@thomas where's the "Like" button?
@nathan - probably the idea was scrapped - i think they'd benefit even more from a dislike-button....

Our team has the desire/need to allow a few users to edit the workflows in their respective projects, yet they do not belong as global JIRA Administrators. My priority would point us to allowing Edit Workflows as a separate permission to manage in JIRA.

Editing workflows is the number one request here too, followed closely by editing permission schemes.

It would be awesome to extend the current permissions framework to include these schemes, so that members of the administrators project role could perform these edits.

I myself would rather see a configurable Project Administrator role that allowed the JIRA Administrator the ability to assign specific configurations that the Project Administrator would be permitted to manage and modify.

For example, we now have a very strict permissions policy in place due to the configuration chaos that was created by allowing too many users JIRA Administrator permissions because we couldn't restrict what they could and could not modify, and we ended up with a resolution named "Unresolved", which as you could imagine was a VERY BAD IDEA!

I know many have requested the addition of workflow design and modification for the Project Admins, but the problem with allowing workflow modifications is you would also have to allow permissions to create statuses too, unless of course you were able to lock down status creation, but still allow workflow creation/modification.

In our case, we would like to keep most core configurations locked down to JIRA Admin only, but have a level of administration that would permit user creation to take some of the light admin work off of the plate of our core JIRA Admin group. Maybe a jira-user-administrators group and associated role.

Anyway, not sure a configurable Administrator will ever come to be or even a limited JIRA Admin role, but that's my $0.02 on the subject.

@Terry Beavers
You too? The "Unresolved" resolution is more popular than I thought

Thanks for pointing out the status thing; no I don't want them making statuses either. But, they don't need to do that to create a workflow; they can use existing statuses, or request that a new one be created by their admin.

I just don't want to be editing workflows all day because the slightest little tweak requires a Jira Admin.

I think the system roles and permission schemes are great as they are, and I've already configured my schemes to be entirely role-based (don't want to be running after project-level user perms all day either), but they just need a couple new permissions added for editing the assigned schemes (or not editing them, as the case may be).

However; on the contrary we do not want project administrators to have the ability to edit workflows. We have our workflows setup by scheme and is done for one is done for a block - some times in upto 50. As a result we control who can access and edit workflows. At the minute that means only a select number of staff have the ability to jira-administrator. We would prefer to tighten not loosen the administration functions.

So in other words this is not a one size fits all conversation.

I think the trouble with this is that workflows cant be effectively modified while in use in JIRA's current setup You can create a draft yes, but you cant remove or edit statuses while they are in use. There has to be a way setup to branch off a actually copy of the workflow in use rather than just a draft, edit it, and the switch workflows, but have it isolated so the project admins cant edit another project's workflow. All these permissions need to be given and removed through the permission scheme rather than granted by default. This way those of us who have projects with different workflows and would like our admins to be able to manage them can, while people like Lyn who have heavily shared workflows can restrict the access and keep it secured.

Following all of these comments it is apparent that what we are missing is details of the planned changes (aside of the planned dates). This would help us all so that we can plan our instances to be ready to take these changes as (when?) they are introduced.

For example, custom fields. Will a project administrator need to be an admin of all projects that use a custom field or just the specific context related to their project? How will a new custom field be made available to other projects? Etc.

Any chance of a preliminary spec please guys?
The workflows shouldn't be an issue, since project administrators can essentially modify simplified agile workflows on their own. The technology is there!

Yes, in Agile, admins can modify the simple workflow to a degree... But if your not using or paying for agile, or have highly configured workflows in several different plans, then this becomes a necessary ability.

We don't want to allow project admin to modify workflow. ability to update custom field values for their project is a good feature. but please don't add project admins to update workflows. we only want true admins to update/add workflow.

[^benjamin_joyner] I absolutely agree. My thoughts were that the bits to allow Project Administrators to modify workflows are already built. Trust me, I'm not saying that people shouldn't be able to modify these. I'm saying that, overall, permissions need to be more granular. Some people don't want certain users to be able to modify custom fields, so fine, ensure that they don't have the necessary permissions to do so. It boils down to an overall issue with the lack of permissions that are able to be granted.

At this point, it would be nice for Project Administrators to update permission & notification schemes.

@Samip Banker
I don't think anyone wants unfettered access for project admins to edit workflows.

I think what is needed is a permission scheme change to allow adding a project role (or user or group) to a workflow edit permission, similar to the way all other permissions are managed in Jira now.

That's the only sensible way to keep project admins from editing other project's workflows, or give new admins time to understand Jira before being granted this right, or a hundred other scenarios that don't need to be coded for individually. With this model, you don't have to grant anyone the permission if you don't want to

this should be simple - dont allow any other than the jira admins to modify the core system to any extend - ie. workflows, custom fields, any schemes (perm & notif), roles etc etc.
The projects workflows should rather be setup from a generic approach - for instance do i host 440 projects using only one permission scheme, one notification scheme, one workflow, one of each configuration, the only thing that varies is which custom fields are enabled. Imagine if one of the 440 Project Leads suddenly changed the workflow even a tiny bit or if he changed the permission scheme, reflecting changes for 439 other projects and nearly 2000 active users would have to realize a system change they might not understand. Furthermore documnetation would be spoiled and the instrumentation from the admin would be impossible - it would be a mess, without a doubt. Therefor - NEVER allow other than jira/system-admins to change the core, the basics and the structure. But always allow Project leads to change attributes for a project (versions, assign to roles, etc) - and then PL must request feature changes from jira admins, thats the only way to keep a sane system.

thats my 2 cents.

When this is said - i seriously doubt Atlassian would ever consider to change anything that requires development requested by the users - i strongly suspect them to close this issue due to age or any other ridiculous excuse within a year or two... since the issue is 10 years old its now grown up to be rejectable
But thats just my next 2 cents.. have a nice day

Probably naive here, but seems like a pretty good candidate to iterate on:

The natural starting point is to provide a role that allows members to create a project and associates that member as the project creator/owner upon creation. That's all* it needs to do. To me, everything else from there is icing.

We want to enforce templates (workflows, permission schemes, issues, screens, etc) at a global level. We just need a way to enable a subset of our general developer pool to create a project on demand.

Also, the project creator plugin is a non-starter for us b/c we are using the OnDemand product

  • I understand that it's never this simple. Perhaps it's a testament to the rest of the UX that this seems like something that should be that simple? Regardless, project creation is the single barrier to adoption within our organization because we are not willing to open up full-admin of the platform to this set of users.

centralize it - even project creation, or it would seem to me that you could end up having the same project created multible times in different names, or with different users assigned - spoiling consistency in your data.. maybe someone has bindings on projectnames to systems like SVN, TIMEREG or CRMs... if bonanza is set loose, i'd wave goodbye to reliable consistent data

Kay...

we have used "Project Creator" plugin (https://wittified.atlassian.net/wiki/display/PCFJ/Project+Creator+for+JIRA) to allow sub set of users to create project based on the template... and this template has all schema, flows, etc already populated. so when project is created by non-JIRA admin those project always has correct intended info.

Simple use case..

I have
Team Lead "A"
Team Lead "B"

Projects:
Team Lead "A" Project 1 - WorkflowA-1
Team Lead "A" Project 2 - WorkflowA-1
Team Lead "B" Project 1 - WorkflowB-1
Team Lead "B" Project 2 - WorkflowB-1
Confidential Projects - WorkflowC

I want Team Lead "A" to be able to manage WorkflowA, Team Lead "B" to be able to manage WorkflowB and global administrator to be able to administer the rest. Using the agile workflow thing doesn't work as I want to have the same workflow used in multiple projects. Granting Lead A or B global admin doesn't work as they should not have access to Confidential Project.

The answer is quite simple, just allow the ability to grant permission for Team Lead "A" to modify Workflow A. Seems simple doesn't it? Why is this open for 10 years. As this functionality doesn't exist, it forces the workflow maintenance on the global admin, who should be doing other things...

Adam:

Your usecase may be valid for you but opening modifying workflow to project admin/lead is a show stopper. we don't want project admin/leads ability to update workflows.

So what ever is the implementation.... Atlassian should make sure it supports all use case.
then don't grant the permission that would allow the lead to modify the workflow... it's optional in the enhancement I suggested as well as a few others earlier.

Frankly I'm not happy with the suggestion from Malik, whose comment appears to have been deleted by Atlassian, suggesting that a third party company "clearvision-cm.com" is going to implement this functionality as a paid-for add-on, because Atlassian are obviously too slack to do anything about it themselves.

My company is most likely not going to renew our maintenance support for Jira + Agile next year (500 user license) precisely because Atlassian drag their feet on implementing useful functionality such as this. We see no benefit in paying $8,000 for upgrades that gives us no added value.

Sort your shit out, Atlassian.

@Greg Hoggarth, Lets have a party, we have a lot in common.. it makes no sense paying huge sums for "support and maintenance" when there is none... i host 2000 user license, so the business is even worse..

@Greg Hoggarth, Lets have a party, we have a lot in common.. it makes no sense paying huge sums for "support and maintenance" when there is none... i host 2000 user license, so the business is even worse..

Please accept my apologies if I have miscommunicated the information.

This is an update to let you know that we plan to restart our efforts around improving project administration. Obviously it's quite a complex project, with several big components.

But overall, administration is an area that we believe should be part of the core JIRA project and not offered as an add-on, and we do intend to deliver meaningful improvements in the year ahead.
We have 10,000 user license (and growing) and this feature is badly needed.
It seems that money talks...

Personally.. it seems to me this is all around how you use jira. Some parts of our instance is highly dynamic and can change on daily basis (fields) and other parts we do not want normal users within coooeee of.

From what I can see the current project administrator function provides much of what I want (together with an addon for Edit Custom Fields). So to me this conversation is a non conversation. And as there are so many different views any wonder why it is open for so long. They either cant be bothered or its all too hard - which will be my bet when the finally get around to closing this. Words to the effect "we are unable to do this as it breaks a fundamental rule on which jira is built" aka its too hard.

Sorry, but the fundamental purpose of Jira is to aid productivity. Productivity is not aided (in many organisations) by having a bottleneck on who can perform certain activities and who cannot.

It's a pity they didn't work on this over a decade ago when it was first raised, because architectural system functionality like this is always harder to retrofit into place, rather than baking it in up-front to begin with.

Has Altassian considered a permissions approach that would allow project admins to edit their own workflows if they are not shared? While this does not address the whole issue I think it would get a lot of us in better place to allow other teams to self serve.

We saw that this ticket was created februari 2004, is there any news about a beter rights system in Jira. We now need to make every project manager a jira administrator otherwise they can not create any projects.
I just need to give my team leads access to creating versions. No other Admin rights. Right now, having to come to me for a new version causes all sorts of dificulties.

@dpeugeot - I didn't think that required anything more than the administrator role on a given project? I know I'm not creating versions for projects in my Jira and I definitely don't have anyone other than myself with full admin rights.

Correct. But I DON'T want to give people Project Admin rights - particularly the ability to edit Roles. Plus, I have certain steps in the workflow locked down to PM level or higher, and I DON'T want to give our team leads the ability to transition to certain states.

@Deanna; you have a similar problem that we have, which is why we don't use role based permission schemes until we can restrict the Project Admin's ability to add groups to a project. I can't tell you how many times a desperate project admin has added jira-users to their project.

We use group based permission schemes which are controlled by Jira admins-- and then allow project admins to do whatever they want, since they can't really do much damage without access to roles.

I really hope Atlassian can separate out project access from Agile board management. Those are definitely two different levels of administration.
@Deanna correct; for same reason it's important for me.

I am currently investigating for a JIRA plugin to allow additionally project roles, groups or users (not only project admins) to manage versions. If you are interested in such a plugin, please contact me via email. Would be great to get in contact to discuss your requirements and different options in implementation.

Best regards
Holger

A possible workaround for this issue could be to:

  • Create a staging JIRA instance, with identical data as your live one
  • Grant system administrator access to the users you'd otherwise grant project administrator role to create workflows
    • Let them create/modify/test their workflows
  • Use the workflow import/export method to transfer these workflows to your live instance: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Sharing+your+workflow. (be aware of JRA-37358)

It would be great in JIRA to have admin for each Projects who will be having permission to modify configurations of only that Project in which he is admin..

He should not be able to modify any other project but he should have full eprmissions for his project.

Please suggest if any solution is there?

Thanks,
Nidhi

Completely disagree with most comments here. This would be a recipe for disaster in an enterprise deployment. Most project admins lack the understanding of the components and dependencies that exist in a best practices rollout of JIRA. In most cases workflows, screens, and other scheme's are shared across multiple projects and the average project administrator has no idea of the impacts of the small change they want to implement on "their" project. Dedicated JIRA administrators know what to look for and think about when a change to a project is requested and can head of a simple but disastrous change that could be made to a project.

Fundamentally, there is no way that Atlassian can allow anyone other than a full jira admin to edit workflows since they have the potential to execute arbitrary code depending on what add-ons you have installed (i.e. ScriptRunner).

However, it should be completely reasonable for a project level admin to be able to edit a lot MORE than they are currently able to edit. Additionally, it really should not be necessary to have full admin privileges to be able to edit certain shared components of the system that are currently restricted.

Example of something a project should be able to be configured to allow to do - select an existing workflow or other schemes that are already predefined.

I am in agreement with others that have suggested that any change for this should be something that is configurable with roles/permissions/etc - it shouldn't be a blanket change opening up the additional access.

@Andrew Morin - I totally get where you're coming from.

That said, an enterprise installation needs delegation, and an ability to "grow" new Jira administrators within a suitable structure.

The current application's all-or-nothing approach makes knowledge transfer and experiential growth impossible. Even if we hire someone with Jira experience, they won't know our environment, yet there is no means of gradually increasing their rights within the system.

Additions to the permission scheme structure, as @Nathan Neulinger suggests, solves both system and personnel issues in a way that would make the application truly enterprise-ready, and not just the small-business app with a few enterprise features that we have today.

I think the quickest win for me would just be to have the "Change Project Role Membership" permission separated out from all the other Project Admin functions.

They seem to be subtly different things to me. One is about administering the project itself (components, versions, whatever). Whereas the other is about controlling who gets to do what inside the project.

I would like to be able to devolve the versions, components etc out to my team, but not let them change who is in which role, or grant themselves extra project role privileges, etc.
That would also make sense to me and be very welcome.

I see here so many different wishes what a project admin should do that I am currently happy that Atlassian does nothing. I see no problem, that more people can change also membership roles. At least now this is audited in JIRA. Although this should be kept together with the project: the team itself should be able to track, which configuration changes were done to the project in a Activity Stream.
I am worried that project leads will have the chance for changing workflows or adding custom fields for themselves. In an enterprise environment this must not happen. I would only vote to have project specific value lists in a customized field.

I think the problem is that currently, you have to put up with either:

  • the project administrators being a bottleneck/getting loads of work, because only they can create versions, components, etc
  • allowing anyone who needs to just (eg) create versions to be a full project administrator - but then they can basically mount a coup, by removing you from the project admin role, or giving out access to anyone else they feel like, etc

Neither of these are ideal IMHO.

I agree that there are a log of various requests, but I feel like that just shows that there needs to be changes. Not all of them need to be implemented but something needs to be done (delegated permissions, additional separation of permissions, etc). I am also an enterprise customer and our support group can't scale to manage all the JIRA admin requests that come in. I know the changes are complicated so I agree with the approach that Atlassian is proposing (incremental) as long as we start to see progress for some of them.

Some of the items that are important to us

  1. Adding new values to customized fields
  2. Changing the scheme or workflow for their project (using an existing workflows/schemes - so, no editing of those just picking them)
  3. Create New Project
  4. As a developer/non project admin - create and edit sprints and other agile board permissions (this might actually be a different JIRA issue)
  5. Possibility of adding new custom fields for a given project (I know this is a sticky one so it is lower priority)
Another +1 for the existing Edit Custom Field Values add-on. This takes care of most of our issues managing custom field values.
To allow project administrators to manage option values of selected single and multi select custom fields, you can use Project Specific Select Field.
Hello Holger, that would be great, but the add-on "Project Specific Select Field" is not compatible with Confluence 5.8.10. #fyi
@Martin, Don't get you point. We are talking about JIRA configuration, which has nothing to do with Confluence.

@Holger: You're absolutely right. My fault. But my issue is another. I think a "project group admin" should be able to create new projects, but with this plugin (as a JIRA admin) I must create projects by myself and set the project group admins one by one to make changes for every single project.

I have found a solution to my problem. With the "Project Creator" add-on I was able to add a jira-manager group within members can administrate only projects and no system administration settings anymore (in the permission section).

item.title: [JRA-1431] Create a separate permission for Create New project.
item.description:
Atlassian Update - 6 September 2015

Hi everyone,

Thanks so much for your votes and comments on this feature request.

We plan to work on a larger theme of improving creating, setting up, and maintaining projects over the next 12 months. This is a long-term project with quite a lot of technical complexity. We will be looking at feature requests that are spread out over a number of issues on jira.atlassian.com, including this one and JRA-3156.

The ability to create new projects without full JIRA administrator permission is one of the initial areas we will investigate, so this is a high priority for our team. While we cannot provide any information on a planned solution or release date, we will update this issue as we progress.

Thanks for your patience and we hope you appreciate our open approach to feature requests. Please don't hestitate to contact me with any questions.

Cheers,

Dave Meyer
JIRA Product Management
dmeyer@atlassian.com

Original request description:

Currently, I need to give my project manager the jira-administor permission in order for him to create new projects. Unfortunately, this opens up the possibly of him doing other stuff, like changing the mail server. Not that he would, but when you give permissions...
Suggestion: Make Create New Project a separate global level permission.
item.summary: Create a separate permission for Create New project.

status.description: Issue is open and has not yet been accepted by Atlassian.

comments.comment: It would be nice if the pro version could have this feature as well.

This should be extended to create a poweruser permission level. This level would allow superusers to assign powerusers the permission schemes they can operate under. This scenario allows the powerusers to fully operate as a data administrator thereby alleviating system admins from having to do data administration as is the case now.

I'd like to add my vote to this issue. I work in a large company, and we don't want to proliferate Big-Chair access all over the place. But we DO want lots of people to be able to create new projects. Is this a planned feature?
This would be a really useful feature
This would be tricky, I think. Because obviously they would need the ability to edit the project to set schemes and so forth, and the current interface allows editing existing schemes too.

To me, JIRA Administrators have access rights to everything while Project Administrators have the abilities to create/delete/edit projects. I also believe that a Project Administrator should be able to select schemes, just not edit them.

I would love to see this added. I have people I want to be able to create projects but I don't want to be able to edit various schemes.

It would be nice to have a permission that allows a user to create projects and assign existing schemes to them but not edit the schemes.

On project creation the creating user should be project lead.

I disagree with the priority (set to minor right now) of this.

We'd like to not grant jira-administrators privilege to project/technical managers who only need to be able to create projects and not necessarily see the rest of the administrative controls.

This was reported in 2003. Are you guys planning on implementing this anytime??

Hi,

Due to the large number of other popular requests we currently have no concrete plans to implement this feature.

In my opinion this is one of the basic features and must be implemented.
Even simple free CMS systems have possibilities to make several "admin" levels and specify what administration features will be available for particular user/group.
Why I should give administrator rights to the PM? Sounds really irrational.
We have met that problem, there are many project need to be created by JIRA administrator. we also hope a seperate permission of create project , which can be assigned to project leader.
I have the same problem. This sounds like basics to me, why is there not any solution for it yet?

I agree. I'm new to Jira, and just started setting up Jira 4 for use by my organisation. I have wasted a good bit of time looking for a way to allow project managers to add projects without giving them all the other permissions associated with system administrators, thinking "it must be there somewhere, why can't I find it?". I'm absolutely gobsmacked that this was first suggested six and a half years ago and still (even after a new major release) it has not been implemented. Surely it can't be that hard to implement?
Adding my vote for this feature. No need for non-sysadmins to have sysadmin level rights just to create a project.

About six years Atlassian can't implement this simple feature...
So, I think Atlassian don't know about working with many small projects. It's bad, very bad...
Adding my vote for this feature. we need a role for creating a project.
Addning my vote here. I don´t want to give administrator-rights to enable this function for users.

Voted for this feature as well. We also have lots of small projects and I would like my developers to be able to add a project without having full administration access (not that they would intentionally do "something bad", but limiting access to administrative controls eliminates the possibility of accidentally introducing issues).

I'm waiting for some resolution of this task. Is this will be a role or permission has no matter. The only thing is that many companies are waiting for this.
There is a possition in my company named project manager, which gives him permission to initialization projects, so he should have in jira permission to create projects without aministrative rights.

Adding my vote. There are degrees of admins, and there should be permissions to support it. We have a group of people that should be able to create projects and administer them, without getting the ability to do all the other admin functions. Similarly, we'd like to grant some the ability to modify various schemes without also being able to import and muck with instance setup. There's nice control at the issue level for users - want similar for admin.

As Luke I have the same possition in my company. I want someone to be able to create projects but NOT able to change other people groups or change workflows or permission schemes I think than a custom permission with "read" - "read/modify" for administration groups could be implemented.

this way we could have someone able to see/modify the project group (i.e. create projects) but not see the global settings (and not able to change look&feel i.e)

I think this is a "must have" for jira administration

I also think that it is high time Atlassian provide this feature. Other project management information systems give this capability to users defined as project managers. One place that I've been at, you had to submit an issue to a queue in JIRA to get your project created. Yet the person requesting the new project created had to tell the person what workflow they wanted to use and everything. Talking about inefficient and non-agile in my mind...

We're currently trialling Jira and really need this feature for our project managers.
They really only need to be able to add and manage projects and categories, and possibly add users and assign them to projects.

Full admin rights mean that the admin section is overwhelming for the people organising the projects: they don't need to see things like the permission or system settings.

If our project managers don't like the system then we won't be able to adopt it as a company.
Based on that, this feature should be a must-have. Possibly accompanied by a new default user group for project managers to aid other companies trialling the system.

This issue is a major problem for my employer right now, as well. We need to have a fairly large group of people able to create projects (they are plenty responsible) and select from existing schemes for those projects. At the same time, we need to have most of those people to be unable to do some of the things that anyone with the "JIRA Administrators" privilege can do. Unfortunately, the only way to create projects is to have the "JIRA Administrators" privilege.

For example, we have several sensitive, confidential projects that should not be seen by anyone but the project members. However, anyone with the "JIRA Administrators" privilege can see them.

Funneling all the project creation requests through just a couple of people who have all privileges is not practical; as Charles Cain pointed out that's incredibly inefficient and non-agile.

Not only that, but it's insulting to the project managers to tell them they are responsible for creating projects (in the corporate sense) and managing them once created (in the JIRA sense), but that they cannot be TRUSTED to actually CREATE the JIRA project. That's hardly a way to drive further adoption of JIRA into a company!
Adding my vote.
Adding my vote.Need to have this for my installation as well as giving all employees the administration right is a major securtiy issue,

Really important for us to!
This is a must have feature...

I would like to add my vote to this feature. We are a digital agency and go through a large number of projects. I am wary of allowing our Project Managers to have access to the admin priviliges incase they go clicking where they should not and end up screwing up parts of the system (disabling our user directory comes to mind). A Project Manager should be able todo just that, create projects and manage them, not have to require an admin to goto the effort of doing their job for them.

Please add to the roadmap as this would be really useful.
I'd like to add my vote to this issue.

Have added my vote to this as well, we're a University and would appreciate the ability to assign "Create Projects" permissions to designated administrators within the various faculties and divisions without giving them "God-Mode" access.

Has anyone found a temporary work around until this is implemented other than just giving everybody jira-administrator access?

Adding my vote to this as well. My company is currently piloting JIRA for use in our division and I have found that I can't give access for users to create projects. I am not sure if I, personally, want to allow the creation of workflow, notification, and permission schemes, but I would at least like a set of users to have the ability to create a project and use either a defined template (project categories - what else are they used for?), or select the pre-existing schemes.

In the meantime, I may try a workaround using the command line tool and a Jenkins job that allows users to input the project info, and hit a build button in Jenkins.
This request has been outstanding for years.... when oh when is Create New Project going to be made a separate global level permission?

The more I think about it, the more I think NOT having a role that can create projects... is a REALLY BAD idea. Projects are part of JIRA workflow. There are dashboards, projects, and tickets! None of those has anything to do with setting JIRA up (the admin's job). And once JIRA is set up... NO ONE should have to be admin for day to day work. To me... this is a serious "security" flaw, and should be elevated WAY above a "minor improvement". Instead of having 1 admin, and X users... we are forced to have X admins! And the REAL admin has to worry every day, that someone is going to bork up the system, by changing something they shouldn't, JUST so the right people can create projects! C'mon Atlassian! How many admins on YOUR JIRA???

Exactly the same feelings as Mark above. Well put! This seems must needed functionality not just for the ability to create projects but for the ability to edit permissions at an admin level (not just a project level) - e.g. on our side we need to allow the admin extension to not only add projects but create users as well.
Nearly 9 years later -Im guessing this 'must needed functionality' is not going to be added anytime soon.. Is there a module that can do this?
We need this functionality to continue using JIRA. Currently Atlassian products fail all secuirty reviews. Over 100 votes and 50 watchers, come on Atlassian this is basic stuff.

We are also having the same problem. It is a big security issue. It would be really good to see this issue taken a bit more seriously! Not having an "Add Project" permission means either I have to spend the majority of my time creating projects, or I have to hand out admin rights which allow circumvention of the other permission schemes in place.

Adding my feedback as well. This is a very much needed security enhancement. Other teams in my organization have opted to not use Jira due to security concerns stemming from this issue. Atlassian Status as of 21 January 2013

Hi Everyone,

Thanks so much for your votes and comments on this feature request.

This is a feature that we would like to take a look at in the near future, however right now we can not give you a timeframe. More than likely when we take a look at implementing JRA-3156 we will also take a look at this as well.

Thanks for your patience and please keep up the votes and continue to give us your use cases for this feature.

Cheers,

Roy Krishna
JIRA Product Management
roy at atlassian dot com

This feature request is literally over 11 years old.

In the Global Permissions section there is differentiated between:

  • JIRA System Administrators
    Ability to perform all administration functions. There must be at least one group with this permission.
  • JIRA Administrators
    Ability to perform most administration functions (excluding Import & Export, SMTP Configuration, etc.).

Would it be possible, to add some more, e.g.

  • JIRA Project Administrators
    Ability to perform several administration functions, especially those required by Agile (Creation of Projects, Creation of Boards, Sprints, etc.) since this has to work in connection with Jira.
  • JIRA Road Map Administrators
    Ability to handle the versions and the roadmap in all projects.

In my opinion it would make sence, to handle the topic here and not necessarily in connection with permission schemes only (alt least not for everyone)

Yes actually most project group leads and assignable users just need access to create and manage new users for their project (and potentially update their screens). Unfortunately lumping all admin together means you end up with people trying to create projects they don't actually need and having to undo work that doesn't align with the business processes you have established in Jira.

We recently created three user groups for each project e.g. Group Admins, Group Assignables and Group User, and started transitioning daily project permissions to these groups and shifted more global permissions to the system admin role. However we do not have the ability to allow project leads access to ONLY add and manage users on their group. If we could do this we could devolve some of the admin overhead without worrying about unknowingly doing something elsewhere.

Thanks!
Will this work also include a Create Users permission? I have the same problem where enabling someone to create users allows them to make major changes to my JIRA instance.

Yes exactly basically that is what we would like to allow project leads and assignable users to add new users to Jira and then to their project. Ideally they should manage their users so be able to :

1. Run a report to see all the users and assignable users in my project
2. Add new users to Jira and add them to raise issues on my project
3. Remove them from access to my project ( but from 'my' project - not other peoples projects)

I think this would take a lot of day to day admin away from a few system admins which anyone sensible can do

In my opinion, the goal is to get JRA-3156 (Required: Project Group Administrator) implemented.

@Louise Lister

90% of what you are looking for exists now if your permission schemes rely on project roles. The project admin can see which role has "assignable user" (or any other permission) and add whoever they want to the appropriate role in their project without having any other admin rights in Jira. E.g., I add users to the system, but anything beyond basic access to log in is handled by project admins; not me. Users and assignable users are viewable by project admins on the project role screen. I do not know and have no need to care about which users do what in any project; I only concern myself with defining roles and designing permission schemes that can then be used company-wide.

I would definitely like the ability to separate out global permissions. I want to be able to allow certain users the ability to create projects and add users without having all permissions to everything including billing. I have roles defined at the project level but anything outside of that is all or nothing.

Do we have an estimate on when this will be ready?

It is crazy that Atlassian would delay this capability. Any company that sells software to the U.S. Government, has to obtain security certification (FIPS, Common Criteria (CC), etc). Not being able to separate out a group of users with "create" permissions and full administrator permissions is in violation of common security requirements. This item should be on the top of the priority list as it puts any business using this software at high risk.

There is a vender plugin you can pay for https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.wittified.jira.delegated-admin. However, I work for a Public University on a strict budget and we cannot justify paying for what should be basic functionality.

The Delegated Project Creator add-on by Wittified allows Admins to create "templates" of desired project configurations (permission schemes, notification schemes, field configuration schemes, etc.) and then allow trusted users to can create projects based on those templates.

It also offers add-ons that extend it, to support the notion of Agile Board templates and DEISER Pro Fields as well.
When will https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.wittified.jira.project-creator be available on the cloud?

Hi Lesa King,

This is definitely something we'd like to do and are currently evaluating the technical challenges. Some of the JIRA APIs don't adequate support for porting this functionality to Cloud (see ACJIRA-603 and ACJIRA-597 for example), but we'll keep exploring our options.
